Toponymy    The place name  Niigata  was first recorded in 1520  Eisho 17 .

However  as there is no record about the origin of the name  this had led to several theories.
First  Niigata  was a large lagoon at the mouth of the Shinano river.
Second it was an inland bay at the river s entrance.
Third it was the name of a village that stood on an island within the estuary.

Etymology    The word  Tottori  in Japanese is formed from two kanji characters.

The main rainy season begins in early May in Okinawa  and the rain front gradually moves north.
In late summer and early autumn  typhoons often bring heavy rain.
Responding to rising concern  the government introduced environmental protection laws in 1970.
Japan is the world s fifth largest emitter of carbon dioxide.
In 2020 the government of Japan announced a target of carbon neutrality by 2050.
Japan s legislative organ is the National Diet  a bicameral parliament.
The Constitution of Japan  adopted in 1947  is the oldest unamended constitution in the world.
The main body of Japanese statutory law is called the Six Codes.
Military      Japan is the second highest ranked Asian country in the Global Peace Index 2020.
Japan maintains one of the largest military budgets of any country in the world.
As of 2019  Japan s labor force consisted of 67 million workers.
Japan has a low unemployment rate of around 2.4 percent.
Around 16 percent of the population were below the poverty line in 2017.
Its main exports are motor vehicles  iron and steel products  semiconductors and auto parts.
Japan ranks highly for competitiveness and economic freedom.
It is ranked sixth in the Global Competitiveness Report for 2015–2016.
Only 11.5  of Japan s land is suitable for cultivation.
Because of this lack of arable land  a system of terraces is used to farm in small areas.
Japan s small agricultural sector is highly subsidized and protected.
Japan has sparked controversy by supporting commercial whaling.
Japan s industrial sector makes up approximately 27.5  of its GDP.
For inbound tourism  Japan was ranked 11th in the world in 2019.
However  video gaming in Japan remains a major industry.
The space probe Akatsuki was launched in 2010 and achieved orbit around Venus in 2015.
Japan s plans in space exploration include building a moon base and landing astronauts by 2030.
The largest domestic airport  Haneda Airport in Tokyo  was Asia s second busiest airport in 2019.
Nuclear power was down from 11.2 percent in 2010.
Japan lacks significant domestic reserves and has a heavy dependence on imported energy.
Access to an improved water source is universal in Japan.
About 98  of the population receives piped water supply from public utilities.
In 2019  92  of the total Japanese population lived in cities.
The capital city Tokyo has a population of 13.8 million  2018 .
A growing number of younger Japanese are not marrying or remain childless.
Japan s population is expected to drop to around 100 million by 2050.
Today  1  to 1.5  of the population are Christians.
Almost all children continue their education at a three year senior high school.
The two top ranking universities in Japan are the University of Tokyo and Kyoto University.
Health      Health care is provided by national and local governments.
Another significant public health issue is smoking among Japanese men.

Performing arts      Japanese music is eclectic and diverse.

Noh is one of the oldest continuous theater traditions in the world.

Little is known of the language s prehistory  or when it first appeared in Japan.
Sentence final particles are used to add emotional or emphatic impact  or make questions.
Nouns have no grammatical number or gender  and there are no articles.
Verbs are conjugated  primarily for tense and voice  but not person.
Japanese equivalents of adjectives are also conjugated.
Very little is known about the Japanese of this period.
Old Japanese      Old Japanese is the oldest attested stage of the Japanese language.
Through the spread of Buddhism  the Chinese writing system was imported to Japan.
The end of Old Japanese coincides with the end of the Nara period in 794.
Based on the Man yōgana system  Old Japanese can be reconstructed as having 88 distinct syllables.
The Kojiki has 88  but all later texts have 87.
The distinction between mo1 and mo2 apparently was lost immediately following its composition.
Man yōgana also has a symbol for  je   which merges with  e  before the end of the period.
kwa  and palatalised  kya  consonants are added.
Intervocalic  ɸ  merges with  w  by the 11th century.
Early Modern Japanese gradually evolved into Modern Japanese during the 19th century.
As a result  many elderly people in these countries can still speak Japanese.
The meanings of the two terms are almost the same.
Hyōjungo or kyōtsūgo is a conception that forms the counterpart of dialect.
Hyōjungo is taught in schools and used on television and in official communications.
It is the version of Japanese discussed in this article.
The two systems have different rules of grammar and some variance in vocabulary.
Dialects      Dozens of dialects are spoken in Japan.
Some even differ in vowel and consonant inventories  although this is uncommon.
Within each type are several subdivisions.
Dialects of Tōhoku and North Kantō are associated with typical farmers.
The imperial court also seems to have spoken an unusual variant of the Japanese of the time.
Young people mostly use Japanese and cannot understand the Ryukyuan languages.
Okinawan Japanese is a variant of Standard Japanese influenced by the Ryukyuan languages.
As it stands  only the link to Ryukyuan has wide support.
However  some of these allophones have since become phonemic.
This type of cluster only occurs in onsets.
Consonant length  gemination  is also phonemic.
The stresses differentiate the words.
The basic sentence structure is topic–comment.
For example  Kochira wa Tanaka san desu  こちらは田中さんです .
kochira   this   is the topic of the sentence  indicated by the particle  wa.
As a phrase  Tanaka san desu is the comment.
This sentence literally translates to  As for this person   it  is Mr. Ms.
The topic is zō  elephant   and the subject is hana  nose .
In Japanese  the subject or object of a sentence need not be stated if it is obvious from context.
A single verb can be a complete sentence  Yatta!
I   we   they   etc  did  it ! .
For instance  one does not say in English   The amazed he ran down the street.
Japanese often use titles of the person referred to where pronouns would be used in English.
人人  hitobito  usually written with an iteration mark as 人々 .
Words for people are usually understood as singular.
Thus Tanaka san usually means Mr. Ms.
A group described as Tanaka san tachi may include people not named Tanaka.
For others that represent a change of state  the  te iru form indicates a perfect aspect.
For example  kite iru means  He has come  and is still here    but tabete iru means  He is eating .
In the formal register  the question particle  ka is added.
For example  ii desu  いいです   It is OK  becomes ii desu ka  いいですか。   Is it OK? .
Negatives are formed by inflecting the verb.
Plain negative forms are i adjectives  see below  and inflect as such  e.g.
Pan o tabenakatta  パンを食べなかった。   I did not eat bread .
The word da  plain   desu  polite  is the copula verb.
This comes into use because only i adjectives and verbs can carry tense in Japanese.
For example  Neko ga iru  There s a cat   Ii kangae ga nai   I  haven t got a good idea .
and has been productive in creating modern slang words.
tobidasu  to fly out  to flee   from tobu  to fly  to jump    dasu  to put out  to emit  .
形容動詞 keiyōdōshi  or na adjectives  which are followed by a form of the copula  usually na.
For example  hen  strange  変なひと hen na hito  a strange person .
Examples include ookina  big   kono  this   iwayuru  so called  and taishita  amazing .
The grammatical function of nouns is indicated by postpositions  also called particles.
These include for example   が ga for the nominative case.彼がやった。Kare ga yatta.
に ni for the dative case.田中さんにあげて下さい。 Tanaka san ni agete kudasai  Please give it to Mr.
It is also used for the lative case  indicating a motion to a location.
日本に行きたい。 Nihon ni ikitai  I want to go to Japan.
However  へ e is more commonly used for the lative case.パーティーへ行かないか。 pātī e ikanai ka?
を o for the accusative case.何を食べますか。 Nani o tabemasu ka?
literally   As for me  sushi is good.
As for Mr. Ikeda  he is forty two years old.
Others in the group may also be of that age.
Absence of wa often means the subject is the focus of the sentence.
It is Mr. Ikeda who is forty two years old.
Strangers will also speak to each other politely.
For example  the  san suffix   Mr   Mrs.  or  Miss   is an example of honorific language.
Most nouns in the Japanese language may be made polite by the addition of o  or go  as a prefix.
Such a construction often indicates deference to either the item s owner or to the object itself.
Most Japanese people employ politeness to indicate a lack of familiarity.
This occurs regardless of age  social class  or gender.
A small number of words have come into Japanese from the Ainu language.
Words of different origins occupy different registers in Japanese.
Today most borrowings are from English.
This is when the history of Japanese as a written language begins in its own right.
Over time  a writing system evolved.
However  because of hiragana s accessibility  more and more people began using it.
Japanese students begin to learn kanji from their first year at elementary school.
As for kanji for personal names  the circumstances are somewhat complicated.
Names containing unapproved characters are denied registration.
For this reason  hiragana are appended to kanji to show verb and adjective conjugations.
Hiragana used in this way are called okurigana.

History     Rice is a staple in Japanese cuisine.
Wheat and soybeans were introduced shortly after rice.
During the Kofun period  Buddhism became the official religion of the country.
Therefore  eating meat and fish was prohibited.
In 675 AD  Emperor Tenmu prohibited the eating of horses  dogs  monkeys  and chickens.
In the 8th and 9th centuries  many emperors continued to prohibit killing many types of animals.
During this period  chopsticks were introduced to Japan.
Initially  they were only used by the nobility.
The general population used their hands  as utensils were quite expensive.
Spices were rare to find at the time.
Spices like pepper and garlic were only used in a minimalist amount.
In the absence of meat  fish was served as the main protein  as Japan is an island nation.
Fish has influenced many iconic Japanese dishes today.
In the 9th century  grilled fish and sliced raw fish were widely popular.
Sushi thus became a popular snack food and main entrée  combining fish with rice.
During the Edo period  mid 15th century   sushi without fermentation was introduced.

Ropes have tensile strength and so can be used for dragging and lifting.
Rope is thicker and stronger than similarly constructed cord  string  and twine.
Synthetic fibres in use for rope making include polypropylene  nylon  polyesters  e.g.
Twaron  Technora and Kevlar  and acrylics  e.g.
Some ropes are constructed of mixtures of several fibres or use co polymer fibres.
Wire rope is made of steel or other metal alloys.
Rayon is a regenerated fibre used to make decorative rope.
In metric systems of measurement  nominal diameter is given in millimetres.
Use     Rope has been used since prehistoric times.
Winches and capstans are machines designed to pull ropes.
Such ropes are of kernmantle construction  as described below.
Oppositely   static  ropes have minimal stretch and are not designed to arrest free falls.
They are used in caving  rappelling  rescue applications  and industries such as window washing.
Any rope bearing a GUIANA or CE certification tag is suitable for climbing.
Keeping them away from sharp rock edges is imperative.
Rock climbing ropes are designated as suitable for single  double or twin use.
A single rope is the most common  and is intended to be used by itself.
Smaller diameter ropes are lighter  but wear out faster.
Double ropes are thinner than single  usually 9 mm and under  and are intended for use in pairs.
This adds security in situations where a rope may get cut.
Egyptian rope dates back to 4000 to 3500 BC and was generally made of water reed fibres.
Starting from approximately 2800 BC  rope made of hemp fibres was in use in China.
The cable length was thus set by the length of the available rope walk.
This is related to the unit of length termed cable length.
This allowed for long ropes of up to 300 yards long or longer to be made.
By the late 18th century several working machines had been built and patented.
The handedness of the twist is the direction of the twists as they progress away from an observer.
Thus Z twist rope is said to be right handed  and S twist to be left handed.
Twisted ropes are built up in three steps.
First  fibres are gathered and spun into yarns.
A number of these yarns are then formed into strands by twisting.
The strands are then twisted together to lay the rope.
One property of laid rope is partial untwisting when used.
This can cause spinning of suspended loads  or stretching  kinking  or hockling of the rope itself.
Normal right laid rope should be coiled clockwise  to prevent kinking.
Coiling this way imparts a twist to the rope.
Rope of this type must be bound at its ends by some means to prevent untwisting.
Nylon is chosen for its strength and elastic stretch properties.
However  nylon absorbs water and is 10–15  weaker when wet.
It has somewhat better UV resistance  and is more abrasion resistant.
The strands can interlock with either twill or plain weave.
It is not as round as twisted rope and coarser to the touch.
This construction exposes all fibres as well  with the same drawbacks as described above.
Due to its excellent energy absorption characteristics  it is often used by arborists.
It is also a popular rope for anchoring and can be used as mooring warps.
This type of construction was pioneered by Yale Cordage.
Endless winding is pioneered by SmartRigging and FibreMax.
To prevent kinking it is usually coiled.
There is no substitute for a properly made whipping.
Serious inspection should be given to line after that point.
However  the use to which a rope is put affects frequency of inspection.
Ropes may be flemished into coils on deck for safety   presentation  and tidiness.
Care should be taken around lines under load.

A line may get a further distinction  for example sail control lines are known as “sheets”   e.g.
A halyard is a line used to raise and lower a sail  typically  with a shackle on its sail end.
Other maritime examples of “lines” include anchor line  mooring line  fishing line  marline.
Common items include clothesline and a chalk line.
In some marine uses the term rope is retained  such as man rope  bolt rope  and bell rope.

Effectiveness of embargo    The embargo lasted from October 1973 to March 1974.
Night of October 8—Israel goes on full nuclear alert.
Kissinger is notified on the morning of October 9.
United States begins to resupply Israel.
This followed similar Soviet moves to supply the Arab side.
October 17—OAPEC oil ministers agree to use oil to influence the West s support of Israel.
They recommended an embargo against non complying states and mandated export cuts.
Libya immediately proclaims an embargo on oil exports to the US.
Saudi Arabia and other Arab oil producing states follow the next day.
October 26—The Yom Kippur War ends.
November 5—Arab producers announce a 25  output cut.
A further 5  cut is threatened.
November 23—The Arab embargo is extended to Portugal  Rhodesia and South Africa.
December 25—Arab oil ministers cancel the January output cut.
Saudi oil minister Ahmed Zaki Yamani promises a ten percent OPEC production rise.
January 7–9  1974—OPEC decides to freeze prices until April 1.
January 18—Israel signs a withdrawal agreement to pull back to the east side of the Suez Canal.
February 11—Kissinger unveils the Project Independence plan for US energy independence.
March 5—Israel withdraws the last of its troops from the west side of the Suez Canal.
May 31—Diplomacy by Kissinger produces a disengagement agreement on the Syrian front.
Effects          Immediate economic effects      The effects of the embargo were immediate.
OPEC forced oil companies to increase payments drastically.
The oil exporting nations began to accumulate vast wealth.
Much went for arms purchases that exacerbated political tensions  particularly in the Middle East.
It came in the form of an embargo and production cutbacks from the Arab states.
The weapon was aimed at the United States  Great Britain  Canada  Japan and the Netherlands.
Production was eventually cut by 25 .
Macroeconomic problems consisted of both inflationary and deflationary impacts.
OPEC member states raised the prospect of nationalization of oil company holdings.
As other OPEC nations followed suit  the cartel s income soared.
Saudi Arabia undertook a series of ambitious five year development plans.
The biggest began in 1980  funded at  250 billion.
Other cartel members also undertook major economic development programs.
State governments asked citizens not to put up Christmas lights.
Oregon banned Christmas and commercial lighting altogether.
The EEC was unable to achieve a common policy during the first month of the embargo.
It issued a statement on November 6  after the embargo and price rises had begun.

OPEC duly lifted its embargo from all EEC members.
The price rises had a much greater impact in Europe than the embargo.

A forest is an area of land dominated by trees.
It does not include land that is predominantly under agricultural or urban land use.
Roughly 80 percent of the world’s forest area is found in patches larger than 1 million hectares.
Forests provide ecosystem services to humans and serve as tourist attractions.
Forests can also affect people s health.
Land use definitions are based upon the primary purpose that the land serves.
For example  a forest may be defined as any land that is used primarily for production of timber.
Such definitions typically define a forest as an area growing trees above some threshold.
The precise origin of Medieval Latin foresta is obscure.
These hunting forests did not necessarily contain many  if any  trees.
Unlike forest  these are all derived from Old English and were not borrowed from another language.
Archaeopteris quickly spread throughout the world  from the equator to subpolar latitudes.
Archaeopteris was deciduous  dropping its fronds onto the forest floor.
The shade  soil  and forest duff from the dropped fronds created the first forest.
The shed organic matter altered the freshwater environment  slowing it down and providing food.
Layers      A forest is made up of many layers.
The main layers of all forest types are the forest floor  the understory and the canopy.
The emergent layer exists in tropical rainforests.
Decay on the forest floor forms new soil and provides nutrients to the plants.
The forest floor supports ferns  grasses  mushroom and tree seedlings.
Canopy is formed by the mass of intertwined branches  twigs and leaves of the mature trees.
The crowns of the dominant trees receive most of the sunlight.
This is the most productive part of the trees where maximum food is produced.
The canopy forms a shady  protective  umbrella  over the rest of the forest.
Types      Forests can be classified in different ways and to different degrees of specificity.
Boreal forests occupy the subarctic zone and are generally evergreen and coniferous.
Each category is described as a separate section below.
These forests are composed entirely  or nearly so  of coniferous species  Coniferophyta .
However  under some conditions  e.g.
They occur principally in areas of transition from forested to non forested landscapes.
This vegetation is variously called open taiga  open lichen woodland  and forest tundra.
Savannas maintain an open canopy despite a high tree density.
A full grown tree produces about 100 kg of net oxygen per year.
Therefore  they are necessary to mitigate climate change.
For example  a research from 2017  show that forests induce rainfall.
If the forest is cut  it can lead to drought.
Humans have generally decreased the amount of forest worldwide.
This gain is due especially to reforestation in China and Russia.
There is an estimated 726 million ha of forest in protected areas worldwide.
These typically need to be close to where the children live  for practical logistics.
Canada      Canada has about 4 020 000 square kilometres  1 550 000 sq mi  of forest land.
About eight percent of Canada s forest is legally protected from resource development.
In 1935 there was only 1 757 000 hectares of forest  today this has increased by more than 150 .

Land shortage    The most striking feature of Japanese agriculture is the shortage of farmland.

There are few consonant clusters.
The Ainu language also has a pitch accent system.
Generally  words containing affixes have a high pitch on a syllable in the stem.
Nouns can cluster to modify one another  the head comes at the end.
Verbs  which are inherently either transitive or intransitive  accept various derivational affixes.
Ainu does not have grammatical gender.
Like incorporation  applicatives have grown less common in the modern language.
Ainu has a closed class of plural verbs  and some of these are suppletive.

Culture     Traditional Ainu culture was quite different from Japanese culture.
The women tattooed their mouths  and sometimes the forearms.
The soot deposited on a pot hung over a fire of birch bark was used for colour.
The sleeves ended at the wrist or forearm and the length generally was to the calves.
Ainu culture considers earrings  traditionally made from grapevines  to be gender neutral.
The house of the village head was used as a public meeting place when one was needed.
The men used chopsticks when eating  the women had wooden spoons.
Capital punishment did not exist  nor did the community resort to imprisonment.
Beating was considered a sufficient and final penalty.
Hunting      The Ainu hunted from late autumn to early summer.
Ezo deer were a particularly important food resource for the Ainu  as were salmon.
They also hunted sea eagles such as white tailed sea eagles  raven and other birds.
The Ainu hunted eagles to obtain their tail feathers  which they used in trade with the Japanese.
The Ainu hunted with arrows and spears with poison coated points.
They obtained the poison  called surku  from the roots and stalks of aconites.
The recipe for this poison was a household secret that differed from family to family.
They also used stingray stingers or skin covering stingers.They hunted in groups with dogs.
At that time  bears were weak because they had not fed at all during their long hibernation.
Ainu hunters caught hibernating bears or bears that had just left hibernation dens.
When they hunted bear in summer  they used a spring trap loaded with an arrow  called an amappo.
The Ainu usually used arrows to hunt deer.
Also  they drove deer into a river or sea and shot them with arrows.
For a large catch  a whole village would drive a herd of deer off a cliff and club them to death.
Fishing      Fishing was important for the Ainu.
Spears called  marek  were often used.
Other methods were  tesh  fishing   uray  fishing and  rawomap  fishing.
Many villages were built near rivers or along the coast.
Each village or individual had a definite river fishing territory.
Outsiders could not freely fish there and needed to ask the owner.
Ornaments     Men wore a crown called sapanpe for important ceremonies.
Sapanpe was made from wood fibre with bundles of partially shaved wood.
This crown had wooden figures of animal gods and other ornaments on its centre.
Ninkari was a metal ring with a ball.
Matanpushi and ninkari were originally worn by men.
Furthermore  aprons called maidari now are a part of women s formal clothes.
However  some old documents say that men wore maidari.
Some glass balls came from trade with the Asian continent.
The Ainu also obtained glass balls secretly made by the Matsumae clan.
Housing      A village is called a kotan in the Ainu language.
The average number of families was four to seven  rarely reaching more than ten.
When the Japanese moved to other fishing grounds  Ainu kotan were also forced to accompany them.
The length lay east to west or parallel to a river.
The Ainu have regarded this window as sacred and have been told never to look in through it.
A house had a fireplace near the entrance.
The husband and wife sat on the fireplace s left side  called shiso  .
Children and guests sat facing them on the fireplace s right side  called harkiso .
The house had a platform for valuables called iyoykir behind the shiso.
An altar  nusasan  faced the east side of the house  rorunpuyar .
Traditions     The Ainu people had various types of marriage.
When the betrothed reached a marriageable age  they were told who their spouse was to be.
There were also marriages based on mutual consent of both sexes.
The parents chose her spouse from men who visited her.
If the woman ate the rest  she accepted his proposal.
If she did not and put it beside her  she rejected his proposal.
He sent her a small engraved knife  a workbox  a spool  and other gifts.
Children were raised almost naked until about the ages of four to five.
Even when they wore clothes  they did not wear belts and left the front of their clothes open.
Subsequently  they wore bark clothes without patterns  such as attush  until coming of age.
Children were called by these  temporary  names until the ages of two to three.
They were not given permanent names when they were born.
Some children were named based on their behaviour or habits.
Women were also considered adults at the age of 15–16.
When women reached age 12–13  the lips  hands and arms were tattooed.
When they reached age 15–16  their tattoos were completed.
Thus were they qualified for marriage.

Mission    Akatsuki is a Japanese orbiter mission currently studying the planet Venus.
This larger orbit takes 10 days to complete instead of the originally planned 30 hours.
The solar arrays provide over 700 W of power while in Venus orbit.
The total mass of the spacecraft at launch was 517.6 kg  1 141 lb .
It is the first spacecraft to use a ceramic  silicon nitride  retrofire thruster.
The high gain antenna is flat to prevent heat from building up in it.
Instruments    The scientific payload consists of six instruments.
Finally  the 1.65 μm filter was used during the cruise phase to study the zodiacal light.
Names and messages were printed in fine letters on an aluminium plate and placed aboard Akatsuki.
The probe was found to be in safe hold mode  spin stabilized state with ten minutes per rotation.
JAXA stated on 8 December that the probe s orbital insertion maneuver had failed.
However  the thrust was only about 40 newtons  9.0 lbf   which was 10  of expectations.
A total delta v of 243.8 m s was imparted to the spacecraft.
Akatsuki has enough fuel to continue operating for at least 2 more years as of November 2019.
In September 2017 JAXA scientists named this phenomenon  Venusian equatorial jet .
By 2017  the science team published 3D maps on the Venus atmosphere structure.

Animals range in length from 8.5 micrometres  0.00033 in  to 33.6 metres  110 ft .
They have complex interactions with each other and their environments  forming intricate food webs.
The scientific study of animals is known as zoology.
Historically  Aristotle divided animals into those with blood and those without.
Dogs have been used in hunting  while many terrestrial and aquatic animals were hunted for sports.
The biological definition includes all members of the kingdom Animalia.
In colloquial usage  the term animal is often used to refer only to non human animals.
Animals are eukaryotic and multicellular.
With very few exceptions  animals respire aerobically.
This may be calcified  forming structures such as shells  bones  and spicules.
These fuse to form zygotes  which develop via mitosis into a hollow sphere  called a blastula.
In most other groups  the blastula  undergoes more complicated rearrangement.
In most cases  a third germ layer  the mesoderm  also develops between them.
Animals have evolved numerous mechanisms for avoiding close inbreeding.
Interactions between animals form complex food webs.
Almost all multicellular predators are animals.
Phylogeny     Animals are monophyletic  meaning they are derived from a common ancestor.
Animals are sister to the Choanoflagellata  with which they form the Choanozoa.
Non bilaterian animals      Several animal phyla lack bilateral symmetry.
Among these  the sponges  Porifera  probably diverged first  representing the oldest animal phylum.
Animals in both phyla have distinct tissues  but these are not organised into organs.
They are diploblastic  having only two main germ layers  ectoderm and endoderm.
The tiny placozoans are similar  but they do not have a permanent digestive chamber.
They also have a gut that extends through the basically cylindrical body from mouth to anus.
Most appear to belong to two major lineages  the  protostomes and the deuterostomes.
The basalmost bilaterians are the Xenacoelomorpha.
Protostomes and deuterostomes       Protostomes and deuterostomes differ in several ways.
In deuterostomes  the anus forms first while the mouth develops secondarily.
Echinoderms are exclusively marine and include starfish  sea urchins  and sea cucumbers.
The deuterostomes also include the Hemichordata  acorn worms .
All of these have a body divided into repeating segments  typically with paired appendages.
The ecdysozoans also include the Nematoda or roundworms  perhaps the second largest animal phylum.
These groups have a reduced coelom  called a pseudocoelom.
These two groups have long been considered close relatives because they share trochophore larvae.
Marine fish of many species are caught commercially for food.
A smaller number of species are farmed commercially.
Chickens  cattle  sheep  pigs and other animals are raised as livestock for meat across the world.
Animals have been hunted and farmed for their fur to make items such as coats and hats.
Animals have been used to create vaccines since their discovery in the 18th century.
Poison dart frogs have been used to poison the tips of blowpipe darts.
However  the most kept pet species are mammals  namely dogs  cats  and rabbits.
A wide variety of terrestrial and aquatic animals are hunted for sport.
Animals including insects and mammals feature in mythology and religion.
The signs of the Western and Chinese zodiacs are based on animals.
However  it was based on erroneous  unscientific observations about the nature of reality.

As a result  animism puts more emphasis on the uniqueness of each individual soul.

Geography     Bahrain is a generally flat and arid archipelago in the Persian Gulf.
Bahrain has mild winters and very hot  humid summers.
Arable land constitutes only 2.82  of the total area.
Summer temperatures may reach up to 50 °C  122 °F  under the right conditions.
Rainfall in Bahrain is minimal and irregular.
Precipitation mostly occurs in winter  with an average of 70.8mm of rainfall recorded annually.
Millions of migratory birds pass through the Persian Gulf region in the winter and autumn months.
One globally endangered species  Chlamydotis undulata  is a regular migrant in the autumn.
Bahrain s national bird is the bulbul while its national animal is the Arabian oryx.
And the national flower of Bahrain is the beloved Deena.

Ethnic groups      Bahraini people are ethnically diverse.
Shia Bahrainis are divided into two main ethnic groups  Baharna and Ajam.
The Shia Bahrainis are Baharna  Arab   and the Ajam are Persian Shias.
Shia Persians form large communities in Manama and Muharraq.
A small minority of Shia Bahrainis are ethnic Hasawis from Al Hasa.
Sunni Bahrainis are mainly divided into two main ethnic groups  Arabs  al Arab  and Huwala.
Sunni Arabs  while a minority  are the most influential ethnic group in Bahrain.
They hold most government positions and the Bahraini monarchy are Sunni Arabs.
Sunni Arabs have traditionally lived in areas such as Zallaq  Muharraq  Riffa and Hawar islands.
There are also Sunnis of Baloch origin.
Religion      The state religion of Bahrain is Islam and most Bahraini citizens are Muslim.
The majority of Bahraini Muslims are Shiites.
The country s two Muslim communities are united on some issues  but disagree sharply on others.
Christians in Bahrain make up about 14.5  of the population.
There is a native Christian community in Bahrain.
Non Muslim Bahraini residents numbered 367 683 per the 2010 census  most of whom are Christians.
Alees Samaan  a former Bahraini ambassador to the United Kingdom is a native Christian.
Bahrain also has a native Jewish community numbering thirty seven Bahraini citizens.
Various sources cite Bahrain s native Jewish community as being from 36 to 50 people.
Languages     Arabic is the official language of Bahrain  though English is widely used.
Nepali is also widely spoken in the Nepalese workers and Gurkha Soldiers community.
Malayalam  Tamil  Bangla and Hindi are spoken among significant Indian communities.
All commercial institutions and road signs are bilingual  displaying both English and Arabic.

Chemical substances can be simple substances  chemical compounds  or alloys.
Chemical substances may be combined or converted to others by means of chemical reactions.
The CAS index also includes mixtures.
This is now known as the law of constant composition.
Some elements can occur as more than a single chemical substance  allotropes .
For instance  oxygen exists as both diatomic oxygen  O2  and ozone  O3 .
The majority of elements are classified as metals.
These are elements with a characteristic lustre such as iron  copper  and gold.
Metals typically conduct electricity and heat well  and they are malleable and ductile.
Around a dozen elements  such as carbon  nitrogen  and oxygen  are classified as non metals.
All compounds are substances  but not all substances are compounds.
Compounds containing bonds between carbon and a metal are called organometallic compounds.
Compounds in which components share electrons are known as covalent compounds.
Compounds consisting of oppositely charged ions are known as ionic compounds  or salts.
Generally  these are called isomers.
A common example is glucose vs. fructose.
The former is an aldehyde  the latter is a ketone.
Their interconversion requires either enzymatic or acid base catalysis.
A common example is glucose  which has open chain and ring forms.
Mixtures contain more than one chemical substance  and they do not have a fixed composition.
In principle  they can be separated into the component substances by purely mechanical processes.
Butter  soil and wood are common examples of mixtures.
The resulting compound has all the properties of a chemical substance and is not a mixture.
Bulk chemicals are usually much less complex.
An alternative system is used by the Chemical Abstracts Service  CAS .
Also it is difficult to keep the track of them in the literature.
This information is compiled as a database and is popularly known as the Chemical substances index.

However  the military weakness of the Song army was observed by the Jurchen Jin dynasty.
In 1127  Emperor Huizong of Song and the capital Bianjing were captured during the Jin–Song Wars.
In the early years of the Ming dynasty  China s capital was moved from Nanjing to Beijing.
The Chongzhen Emperor committed suicide when the city fell.
The ill fated anti foreign Boxer Rebellion of 1899–1901 further weakened the dynasty.

Han characters    are logograms developed for the writing of Chinese.
Chinese characters are the oldest continuously used system of writing in the world.
There are various national standard lists of characters  forms  and pronunciations.
A character almost always corresponds to a single syllable that is also a morpheme.
Cognates in the several varieties of Chinese are generally written with the same character.
Words have also been created by adding affixes  reduplication and borrowing from other languages.
Polysyllabic words are generally written with one character per syllable.
For the 500 most common characters  the proportion rises to 30 .
Often these readings are similar in sound and related in meaning.
In many cases the pronunciations diverged due to subsequent sound change.

折 has readings  tjat   tsyet   zhé  to bend  and  djat   dzyet   shé  to break by bending .

Chinese legal tradition     The word for law in classical Chinese was fǎ  法 .

Under Legalism  law is to be publicly promulgated standards of conduct backed by state coercion.
The idea is that people will internalize the acceptable norms and only take proper actions.
This is not done by dictatorship but by setting an example.
Therefore  a ruler needs not to force his people to behave properly.
This is due to the legalists’ belief that all human beings are born evil and self interested.
It also makes it irrelevant whether the ruler has superior abilities.
Therefore  like Confucianism  Legalism is subject to abuse as well.
For example  books were burned and people holding different ideals were buried alive.
It is true that neither theory is ideal in achieving a social order.
Most legal professionals were not lawyers but generalists trained in philosophy and literature.
For example  li could be enforced by moral influence and legal means.
During the Qing dynasty  criminal justice was based on extremely detailed Great Qing Legal Code.
This often led to the use of torture  in order to extract the necessary confession.
These elements still influence modern Chinese views toward law.
Attitudes toward the traditional Chinese legal system changed markedly in the late 20th century.

A city  市  shi  is a local administrative unit in Japan.
Like other contemporary administrative units  they are defined by the Local Autonomy Law of 1947.
Many municipalities gained city status under this eased standard.
Tokyo also has several other incorporated cities  towns and villages within its jurisdiction.
By 1945  the number of cities countrywide had increased to 205.
As of October 1 2018  there are 792 cities of Japan.
A lawsuit is a proceeding by a party or parties against another in the civil court of law.
The archaic term  suit in law  is found in only a small number of laws still in effect today.
The defendant is required to respond to the plaintiff s complaint.
A declaratory judgment may be issued to prevent future legal disputes.
The conduct of a lawsuit is called litigation.
The term litigation may also refer to a Criminal procedure.
Litigants are responsible to obtain the suited result and the timing of reaching this result.
This is particularly true in federal systems  where a federal court may be applying state law  e.g.
About 98 percent of civil cases in the United States federal courts are resolved without a trial.
Lawsuits can become additionally complicated as more parties become involved  see joinder .
While online searches are appropriate for many legal situations  they are not appropriate for all.
At the time the defendant files an answer  the defendant also raises all  affirmative  defenses.
The defendant may also assert counterclaims for damages or equitable relief against the plaintiff.
Filing an answer  joins the cause  and moves the case into the pre trial phase.
Many courts have a pro se clerk to assist people without lawyers.
After this occurs  the judge or jury renders their decision.
The prevailing party may appeal  for example  if they wanted a larger award than was granted.
Some lawsuits go up and down the appeals ladder repeatedly before final resolution.
There  a new trial will be held and new information taken into account.
Judgments are typically a monetary award.
A defendant who has no assets in any jurisdiction is said to be  judgment proof.
The term is generally a colloquialism to describe an impecunious defendant.
An example of that distinction survives today in the codified text of the Third Enforcement Act.
Americans also use  claim  to describe a demand filed with an insurer or administrative agency.
If the case ultimately loses  the litigant does not have to pay any of the money funded back.
It can be beneficial in many situations  however also detrimental in others.
Civil law is a legal system originating in mainland Europe and adopted in much of the world.
It holds case law secondary and subordinate to statutory law.
Civil law is often paired with the inquisitorial system  but the terms are not synonymous.
There are key differences between a statute and a code.
Codes explain the principles of law  rights and entitlements  and how basic legal mechanisms work.
Other major legal systems in the world include common law  Islamic law  Halakha  and canon law.
Except for the highest courts  all publication of legal opinions are unofficial or commercial.
Roman law was received differently in different countries.
It became the basis of Scots law  though partly rivaled by received feudal Norman law.
The codification typical of modern civilian systems did not first appear until the Justinian Code.
The use of custumals from influential towns soon became commonplace over large areas.
Those ideals required certainty of law  recorded  uniform law.
So  the mix of Roman law and customary and local law gave way to law codification.
Also  the notion of a nation state implied recorded law that would be applicable to that state.
There was also a reaction to law codification.
Germany  1900   and Switzerland  1912  adopted their own codifications.
The Swiss version was adopted in Brazil  1916  and Turkey  1926 .
Despite their differences  the two systems are quite similar from a historical point of view.
Both evolved in much the same way  though at different paces.
Former colonies include Quebec  Canada  and Louisiana  U.S. .
The Chilean Code is an original work of jurist and legislator Andrés Bello.
Hong Kong  although part of China  uses common law.
The Basic Law of Hong Kong ensures the use and status of common law in Hong Kong.
Some systems of civil law do not fit neatly into this typology  however.
Polish law developed as a mixture of French and German civil law in the 19th century.
Louisiana private law is primarily a Napoleonic system.
In Louisiana  private law was codified into the Louisiana Civil Code.
In fact  any innovation  whether private or public  has been decidedly common law in origin.
By contrast  Quebec private law has innovated mainly from civil sources.
Several Islamic countries have civil law systems that contain elements of Islamic law.

Oligopoly     Oligopolies are another form of imperfect competition market structures.
Similar factors that allow monopolies to exist also facilitate the formation of oligopolies.
In the long run  demand is highly elastic  meaning that it is sensitive to price changes.
In the short run  economic profit is positive  but it approaches zero in the long run.
Examples of monopolistic competition include  restaurants  hair salons  clothing  and electronics.

It is a part of the collection of holidays known as Golden Week.

It is effectively a successor to Greenwich Mean Time  GMT .
The coordination of time and frequency transmissions around the world began on 1 January 1960.
This change also adopted leap seconds to simplify future adjustments.
See the  Current number of leap seconds  section for the number of leap seconds inserted to date.
Etymology    The official abbreviation for Coordinated Universal Time is UTC.
UTC is used in many Internet and World Wide Web standards.
For sub microsecond precision  clients can obtain the time from satellite signals.
UTC is also the time standard used in aviation  e.g.
The International Space Station also uses UTC as a time standard.
Mechanism    UTC divides time into days  hours  minutes and seconds.
Each day contains 24 hours and each hour contains 60 minutes.
Thus  in the UTC time scale  the second and all smaller time units  millisecond  microsecond  etc.
are of constant duration  but the minute and all larger time units  hour  day  week  etc.
The extra second is called a leap second.
The irregular day lengths mean that fractional Julian days do not work properly with UTC.
These discontinuities take the form of leap seconds implemented by a UTC day of irregular length.
As with TAI  UTC is only known with the highest precision in retrospect.
Such approximations are designated UTC k   where k is an abbreviation for the time laboratory.
See the article on International Atomic Time for details.
TAI is also commonly used by systems that cannot handle leap seconds.
Since the NATO phonetic alphabet word for Z is  Zulu   UTC is sometimes known as  Zulu time .
This is especially true in aviation  where  Zulu  is the universal standard.
He referred to the resulting system as Cosmic Time.
This agreed with civil Greenwich Mean Time  GMT   used on the island of Great Britain since 1847.
Until the 1950s  broadcast time signals were based on UT  and hence on the rotation of the Earth.
In 1955  the caesium atomic clock was invented.
The jumps increased in size to 0.1 second.
The length of second so defined was practically equal to the second of ephemeris time.
This was the frequency that had been provisionally used in TAI since 1958.
Thus it would be necessary to rely on time steps alone to maintain the approximation of UT.
At the same time  the tick rate of UTC was changed to exactly match TAI.
UTC also started to track UT1 rather than UT2.

As a result  the SI second is close to 1 86400 of a mean solar day in the mid‑19th century.

Shugo daimyo     The shugo daimyo  守護大名  were the first group of men to hold the title daimyo.
They arose from among the shugo during the Muromachi period.
They accumulated these powers throughout the first decades of the Muromachi period.
Eventually some of these in turn came to reside in Kyoto  appointing deputies in the provinces.
The Ōnin War was a major uprising in which shugo daimyo fought each other.
At the end of the fifteenth century  those shugo daimyo who succeeded remained in power.
New to the ranks of the daimyo were the Asakura  Amago  Nagao  Miyoshi  Chōsokabe  Hatano  and Oda.
These came from the ranks of the shugodai and their deputies.
Additional sengoku daimyo such as the Mōri  Tamura  and Ryūzōji arose from the jizamurai.

Denmark lies southwest of Sweden and south of Norway  and is bordered to the south by Germany.
The areas of Denmark and Norway remained under the same monarch until 1814  Denmark–Norway.
After the Second Schleswig War in 1864  Denmark lost the Duchy of Schleswig to Prussia.
It establishes a constitutional monarchy organised as a parliamentary democracy.
The inhabitants of Denmark are there called tani   danɪ    or  Danes   in the accusative.
Denmark has been inhabited since around 12 500 BC and agriculture has been evident since 3900 BC.
The remaining Jutish population in Jutland assimilated in with the settling Danes.
They colonised  raided  and traded in all parts of Europe.
The Danish Vikings were most active in the eastern and southern British Isles and Western Europe.

Denmark tried but failed to regain control of Scania in the Scanian War  1675–1679 .
This led to the so called Danish British Gunboat War.
A new constitution established a two chamber parliament.
Denmark was defeated and obliged to cede Schleswig and Holstein to Prussia.
After these events  Denmark pursued a policy of neutrality in Europe.
Industrialisation came to Denmark in the second half of the 19th century.
Trade unions developed  starting in the 1870s.
Denmark maintained its neutral stance during World War I.
Denmark was a founding member of European Free Trade Association  EFTA .

The DOI system uses the indecs Content Model for representing metadata.
It is the publisher s responsibility to update the DOI database.
If they fail to do so  the DOI resolves to a dead link leaving the DOI useless.
The DOI system is implemented through a federation of registration agencies coordinated by the IDF.
Since 2015  RFCs can be referenced as doi 10.17487 rfc….
It uses a managed registry  providing social and technical infrastructure .
Several approaches for making identifiers persistent have been proposed.
To resolve a DOI name  it may be input to a DOI resolver  such as doi.org.
This approach allows users to click on the DOI as a normal hyperlink.
Other DOI resolvers and HTTP Proxies include http   hdl.handle.net  and https   doi.pangaea.de .
This plug in can also replace references to web to handle proxy servers with native resolution.
The IDF holds annual open meetings on the topics of DOI and related issues.
A list of current RAs is maintained by the International DOI Foundation.
The DOI system overall  through the IDF  operates on a not for profit cost recovery basis.

It has also been one of the least trade dependent economies in the 1970 2018 period.
Japan receives exceptionally low levels of foreign investment.

Japan lags behind other developed countries in labor productivity.

In contrast  startup culture is not as prominent in Japan as elsewhere.
History     The economic history of Japan is one of the most studied.
It was densely populated and urbanized.

The greatest role of government was to help provide good economic conditions for business.
In short  government was to be the guide and business the producer.

The shogunate was officially established in Edo  now Tokyo  on March 24  1603  by Tokugawa Ieyasu.
The period came to an end with the Meiji Restoration on May 3  1868  after the fall of Edo.
After Hideyoshi s death  Ieyasu moved quickly to seize control from the Toyotomi clan.
In 1615  the Tokugawa army destroyed the Toyotomi stronghold at Osaka.
The Tokugawa  or Edo  period brought 250 years of stability to Japan.
In the bakuhan  the shōgun had national authority and the daimyō had regional authority.
The feudal hierarchy was completed by the various classes of daimyō.
Closest to the Tokugawa house were the shinpan  or  related houses .
They were twenty three daimyō on the borders of Tokugawa lands  all directly related to Ieyasu.
The shinpan held mostly honorary titles and advisory posts in the bakufu.
By the 18th century  145 fudai controlled much smaller han  the greatest assessed at 250 000 koku.
Members of the fudai class staffed most of the major bakufu offices.
A code of laws was established to regulate the daimyō houses.
The han  once military centered domains  became mere local administrative units.
Japanese adventurers  such as Yamada Nagamasa  used those ships throughout Asia.
Other Europeans who landed on Japanese shores were put to death without trial.
At the top were the emperor and court nobles  kuge   together with the shōgun and daimyō.
Only the peasants lived in the rural areas.
A few upper samurai were eligible for high office  most were foot soldiers.
The samurai were affiliated with senior lords in a well established chain of command.
The shogun had 17 000 samurai retainers  the daimyo each had hundreds.
Most samurai lost their direct possession of the land  the daimyō took over their land.
The daimyō were put under tight control of the shogunate.
The individual had no separate legal rights.
Eta were butchers  tanners and undertakers.
Hinin served as town guards  street cleaners  and executioners.
Other outsiders included the beggars  entertainers  and prostitutes.
Hinin were only allowed inside a special quarter of the city.
Sometimes eta villages were not even printed on official maps.
The eta  hinin and burakumin classes were officially abolished in 1871.
Osaka and Kyoto each had more than 400 000 inhabitants.
Many other castle towns grew as well.
Rice production increased steadily  but population remained stable.
Rice paddies grew from 1.6 million chō in 1600 to 3 million by 1720.
Improved technology helped farmers control the all important flow of water to their paddies.
The daimyos operated several hundred castle towns  which became loci of domestic trade.
Samurai and daimyos  after prolonged peace  are accustomed to more elaborate lifestyles.
The concentration of wealth also led to the development of financial markets.
Each daimyo also had a capital city  located near the one castle they were allowed to maintain.
Merchants invented credit instruments to transfer money  and currency came into common use.
A century after the Shogunate s establishment  problems began to emerge.
The nation had to deal somehow with samurai impoverishment and treasury deficits.
One solution was reactionary—cutting samurai salaries and prohibiting spending for luxuries.
Other solutions were modernizing  with the goal of increasing agrarian productivity.
Others shoguns debased the coinage to pay debts  which caused inflation.
Agriculture      Rice was the base of the economy.
About 80  of the people were rice farmers.
Rice production increased steadily  but population remained stable  so prosperity increased.
Rice paddies grew from 1.6 million chō in 1600 to 3 million by 1720.
Improved technology helped farmers control the all important flow of irrigation to their paddies.
The daimyō operated several hundred castle towns  which became loci of domestic trade.
Large scale rice markets developed  centered on Edo and Ōsaka.
The daimyō collected the taxes from the peasants in the form of rice.
Taxes were high  often at around 40  50  of the harvest.
The rice was sold at the fudasashi market in Edo.
To raise money  the daimyō used forward contracts to sell rice that was not even harvested yet.
These contracts were similar to modern futures trading.
It was during the Edo period that Japan developed an advanced forest management policy.
The policy mandated that only the shōgun and daimyō could authorize the use of wood.
The rule of the people or Confucian man was gradually replaced by the rule of law.
New laws were developed  and new administrative devices were instituted.
The people were to be ruled with benevolence by those whose assigned duty it was to rule.
Government was all powerful but responsible and humane.
Although the class system was influenced by neo Confucianism  it was not identical to it.
Study of mathematics  astronomy  cartography  engineering  and medicine were also encouraged.
Emphasis was placed on quality of workmanship  especially in the arts.
Buddhism and Shinto were both still important in Tokugawa Japan.
Buddhism  together with neo Confucianism  provided standards of social behavior.
Shinto also helped preserve a sense of national identity.
The kokugaku movement emerged from the interactions of these two belief systems.
The Kojiki  Nihon Shoki  and Man yōshū were all studied anew in the search for the Japanese spirit.
Japan was the land of the kami and  as such  had a special destiny.
Art  culture and entertainment      In the field of art  the Rinpa school became popular.
For the first time  urban populations had the means and leisure time to support a new mass culture.
The district was known for being the center of Edo s developing sense of elegance and refinement.
The most popular sport was sumo.
Eating out became popular due to urbanization.
A number of ryotei also opened to serve high class food.
The rise of a merchant class fuelled more demand for elaborate costumes.
These would be worn by women of the merchant class.
Japanese designers started printing designs that were influenced by the Indian patterns.
Especially samurai and wealthy merchants competed to buy inro of high artistic value.
The Tokugawa did not eventually collapse simply because of intrinsic failures.
In this way  a subtle subversion of the warrior class by the chōnin took place.
During the Tokugawa period  there were 154 famines  of which 21 were widespread and serious.
Western intrusions were on the increase in the early 19th century.
By the 1830s  there was a general sense of crisis.
Although it lasted only a day  the uprising made a dramatic impression.
The resulting damage to the bakufu was significant.
The devalued price for gold in Japan was one immediate  enormous effect.
Debate over government policy was unusual and had engendered public criticism of the bakufu.
In the final years of the Tokugawas  foreign contacts increased as more concessions were granted.
The final economic reform of the Tenpō era of 1841–1843 had similar objectives.
Most were ineffective and only worked in some areas.
Some scholars also point to internal activism for political change.
The army and the navy were modernized.
A naval training school was established in Nagasaki in 1855.

A French military mission was established to help modernize the armies of the bakufu.

Education in Japan is compulsory at the elementary and lower secondary levels.
Education prior to elementary school is provided at kindergartens and day care centers.
The programmes for those children aged 3–5 resemble those at kindergartens.
Scholar officials were chosen through an Imperial examination system.
Since their influence could not be raised through war  they competed on the economic field.
Elementary education was imparted as well as writing and morality lessons.
Japan was thriving with the want for enlightenment.
Compulsory education was introduced  mainly after the Prussian model.
The Japan Library Association  or the JLA  was founded in 1892 to promote the library.
These ideas rapidly disseminated through all social classes.
Teachers also use other media  such as television and radio  and there is some laboratory work.
All course contents are specified in the Course of Study for Lower Secondary Schools.
All students are also exposed to industrial arts and homemaking.
Moral education and special activities continue to receive attention.
Beginning with 848 participants in 1987  the program grew to a high of 6 273 participants in 2002.
A small number of schools offer part time programs  evening courses  or correspondence education.
The first year programs for students in both academic and commercial courses are similar.
They include basic academic courses  such as Japanese language  English  mathematics  and science.
However  there is a core of academic material throughout all programs.
Most upper secondary teachers are university graduates.
Approach and subject coverage tends to be uniform  at least in the public schools.
As of 2017  more than 2.89 million students were enrolled in 780 universities.
The 597 remaining four year colleges in 2010 were private.
Assistance is also offered by local governments  nonprofit corporations  and other institutions.
The quality of universities and higher education in Japan is internationally recognized.

Geography     Egypt lies primarily between latitudes 22° and 32°N  and longitudes 25° and 35°E.
At 1 001 450 square kilometres  386 660 sq mi   it is the world s 30th largest country.
Winds create prolific sand dunes that peak at more than 30 metres  100 ft  high.
Egypt includes parts of the Sahara desert and of the Libyan Desert.
Oases include Bahariya  Dakhla  Farafra  Kharga and Siwa.
Protectorates include Ras Mohamed National Park  Zaranik Protectorate and Siwa.
On 13 March 2015  plans for a proposed new capital of Egypt were announced.
Climate      Most of Egypt s rain falls in the winter months.
A very small amount of snow fell on Cairo on 13 December 2013  the first time in many decades.
Frost is also known in mid Sinai and mid Egypt.
Egypt is the driest and the sunniest country in the world  and most of its land surface is desert.
Egypt has an unusually hot  sunny and dry climate.
The absolute highest temperatures in Egypt occur when the Khamaseen blows.
It is one of the least cloudy and least rainy regions on Earth.
This gave Egypt a consistent harvest throughout the years.
For the grasses  284 native and naturalised species have been identified and recorded in Egypt.

The Emperor of Japan is the head of state and the head of the Imperial Family of Japan.
Imperial Household Law governs the line of imperial succession.
The Supreme Court does not have judicial power over him.
He is also the Head of the Shinto religion.
The Japanese Shinto religion holds him to be the direct descendant of the sun goddess Amaterasu.
The Emperor is also the head of all national Japanese orders  decorations  medals  and awards.
The Imperial House of Japan is the oldest continuing monarchical house in the world.
Naruhito is the current Emperor of Japan.
Earlier  emperors resided in Kyoto  the ancient capital  for nearly eleven centuries.
The Emperor s Birthday  currently 23 February  is a national holiday.

The Japan Self Defense Forces Act of 1954 explicitly vests this role with the prime minister.

Epithet can also refer to an abusive  defamatory  or derogatory phrase.
An epithet is linked to its noun by long established usage.
Not every adjective is an epithet.

An example of a kenning would be using the term whale road instead of the word  sea .

These descriptive phrases can be used in a positive or negative way that benefits the orator.
With persuasion being a key component of rhetoric  it is rational to use epithets.
The use of persuasive wording gives leverage to one s arguments.
Knowledge along with descriptive words or phrases can be a powerful tool.
Orators have a variety of epithets that they can employ that have different meanings.
The most common are fixed epithets and transferred epithets.
A fixed epithet is the repetitive use of the same word or phrase for the same person or object.
A transferred epithet qualifies a noun other than the person or thing it is describing.
This is also known as a hypallage.
Orators take special care when using epithets so as to not use them as smear words.
Orators could be accused of racial or abusive epithets if used incorrectly.

Politics     Estonia is a unitary parliamentary republic.

Estonia has a civil law legal system based on the Germanic legal model.

Local affairs are managed autonomously by local governments.

Eutrophication may also be referred to as dystrophication or hypertrophication.
According to Ullmann s Encyclopedia   the primary limiting factor for eutrophication is phosphate.
Phosphate adheres tightly to soil  so it is mainly transported by erosion.
This decomposition process consumes oxygen  which reduces the concentration of dissolved oxygen.
Eutrophication also decreases the value of rivers  lakes and aesthetic enjoyment.
Elevated levels of atmospheric compounds of nitrogen can increase nitrogen availability.
Coastal waters     Eutrophication is a common phenomenon in coastal waters.
Increased nitrates in soil are frequently undesirable for plants.
Species rich fens can be overtaken by reed or reedgrass species.
However  there is a limit to how much nitrogen can be utilized.
Ecosystems receiving more nitrogen than the plants require are called nitrogen saturated.
This is also the case with increased levels of phosphorus.
Consequently  phosphorus is much more important as a limiting nutrient in aquatic systems.
Since then  it has become more widespread.
Removal of these nutrients is an expensive and often difficult process.
When dissolved oxygen levels decline to hypoxic levels  fish and other marine animals suffocate.
As a result  creatures such as fish  shrimp  and especially immobile bottom dwellers die off.
In extreme cases  anaerobic conditions ensue  promoting growth of bacteria.
Zones where this occurs are known as dead zones.
This process causes shifts in the species composition of ecosystems.
This has been shown to occur in New England salt marshes.
Toxic compounds can make their way up the food chain  resulting in animal mortality.
Freshwater algal blooms can pose a threat to livestock.
An example of algal toxins working their way into humans is the case of shellfish poisoning.
Examples include paralytic  neurotoxic  and diarrhoetic shellfish poisoning.
Assessment    At the most extreme levels  eutrophication is identifiable by sight and smell.
Cleanup measures have been mostly  but not completely  successful.
These efforts have had a 90  removal efficiency.
Still  some targeted point sources did not show a decrease in runoff despite reduction efforts.
See nutrient pollution for an extended explanation of nutrient remediation using shellfish.
The literature suggests  though  that when these sources are controlled  eutrophication decreases.
This suggests that the most effective means of prevention is from the primary source.
Waste disposal technology constitutes another factor in eutrophication prevention.
The role of the public is a major factor for the effective prevention of eutrophication.

Föhn winds can raise temperatures by as much as 14 °C  25 °F  in just a matter of hours.
Causes     There are four known causes of the foehn warming and drying effect.
This mechanism has become a popular textbook example of atmospheric thermodynamics.
Isentropic draw down     Isentropic draw down is the draw down of warmer  drier air from aloft.
This often leads to greater daytime radiative  solar  warming under foehn conditions.
This is a result not only of the warmth of foehn air  but also its low relative humidity.
The causation of Föhnkrankheit  English  Foehn sickness  is unproven.
Evidence for effects from Chinook winds remain anecdotal.
Etymology    The name Foehn  German  Föhn  pronounced  ˈføːn   arose in the Alpine region.
The form phon is used in French speaking parts of Switzerland as well as in Italy.

Racing and strategy     A Formula One Grand Prix event spans a weekend.
A qualifying session is held after the last free practice session.
This session determines the starting order for the race on Sunday.
The current qualifying system was adopted in the 2006 season.
Known as  knock out  qualifying  it is split into three periods  known as Q1  Q2  and Q3.
Drivers are allowed as many laps as they wish within each period.
Currently  with 20 cars  Q1 runs for 18 minutes  and eliminates the slowest five drivers.
Otherwise  all drivers proceed to the race albeit in the worst starting positions.
This rule does not affect drivers in Q2 or Q3.
All of the drivers that did not participate in Q3 have free tyre choice for the start of the race.
Any penalties that affect grid position are applied at the end of qualifying.
The start procedure may be abandoned if a driver stalls on the grid  signalled by raising his arm.
As of the 2019 season  there will always be a standing restart.
In the 1950s  race distances varied from 300 km  190 mi  to 600 km  370 mi .
The maximum race length was reduced to 400 km  250 mi  in 1966 and 325 km  202 mi  in 1971.
The race length was standardised to the current 305 km  190 mi  in 1989.
However  street races like Monaco have shorter distances  to keep under the two hour limit.
Drivers may overtake one another for position over the course of the race.
A driver can be lapped numerous times  by any car in front of them.
However  if the driver has completed more than 90  of the race distance  s he will be classified.
Over the course of a race  drivers must use two of the three available compounds.
If rain tyres are used  drivers are no longer obliged to use both types of dry tyres.
Pit stops are permitted under the safety car.

History    The word emaki stems from the word  emakimono  meaning  picture scrolls .
The first known picture scroll was produced in Japan during the late ninth or tenth century.
The Genji Monogatari picture scroll  however  was produced in the early twelfth century.
Dimensions     The original scroll was about 450 feet long.
It consisted of twenty rolls  contained over 100 paintings  and had over 300 sheets of calligraphy.
It also referred to the painter himself  as opposed to the artist who did the basic drawing.
There are four steps to this process.
In the second step  the piece is executed in a black and white drawing.
Pigments were added to the basic drawing and the details are colored in the third step.
In some cases  interior partitions are omitted.
The artists were very realistic with the architectural details of the scroll.
This technique takes place in all but one of the nineteen pictures in the scroll.
There are only two different viewpoints used to show the faces.
With the right angle the eyebrows and corners of the eyes are seen but the nose is invisible.
They were instead figures of one s imagination from the past or a make believe world.
It was intended for the readers to portray their own image of the figures while reading the novel.
Another way that the artists showed emotion in the characters was by the tilt of their faces.
Some examples that were used throughout the scroll were autumn grasses and raindrops.
The autumn grasses were used as a symbol of human emotion.

History     Ancient humans were present in Germany at least 600 000 years ago.
The first non modern human fossil  the Neanderthal  was discovered in the Neander Valley.
The Nebra sky disk  created during the European Bronze Age  is attributed to a German site.
Under Augustus  Rome began to invade Germania.
In 9 AD  three Roman legions were defeated by Arminius.
Around 260  Germanic peoples broke into Roman controlled lands.
The Ottonian rulers  919–1024  consolidated several major duchies.
Population declined starting with the Great Famine in 1315  followed by the Black Death of 1348–50.
The House of Habsburg held the imperial crown from 1438 until the death of Charles VI in 1740.
The Zollverein  a tariff union  furthered economic unity.
Later  Germany further expanded its colonial empire to include holdings in the Pacific and China.
Germany s new leadership signed the Treaty of Versailles in 1919  accepting defeat by the Allies.
The worldwide Great Depression hit Germany in 1929.
In 1941  German troops invaded Yugoslavia  Greece and the Soviet Union.
They were informally known as West Germany and East Germany.
Konrad Adenauer was elected the first Federal Chancellor of Germany in 1949.
The country enjoyed prolonged economic growth  Wirtschaftswunder  beginning in the early 1950s.
In 2009 the German government approved a €50 billion stimulus plan.
France  Luxembourg and Belgium are situated to the west  with the Netherlands to the northwest.
Germany is also bordered by the North Sea and  at the north northeast  by the Baltic Sea.
There are many species of ferns  flowers  fungi  and mosses.

Politics     Germany is a federal  parliamentary  representative democratic republic.
So far every chancellor has been a member of one of these parties.
The German penal system seeks the rehabilitation of the criminal and the protection of the public.
In 2018  the overall crime rate fell to its lowest since 1992.
Germany is a member of NATO  the OECD  the G8  the G20  the World Bank and the IMF.
The governments of Germany and the United States are close political allies.
It was the world s second biggest aid donor in 2019 after the United States.
In absolute terms  German military expenditure is the 8th highest in the world.

Germany is the largest contributor to the European Space Agency.
Its road network is among the densest in Europe.

The Gini coefficient was proposed by Gini as a measure of inequality of income or wealth.

Limitations    The Gini coefficient is a relative measure.
This is because the Gini coefficient measures relative  not absolute  wealth.
countries may have identical Gini coefficients  but differ greatly in wealth.

Economies with similar incomes and Gini coefficients can have very different income distributions.
Populations can have very low income Gini indices  yet simultaneously very high wealth Gini index.
These factors are not assessed in income based Gini.

In October 1992  TriStar Pictures announced plans to produce a trilogy of Godzilla films.
In May 1993  Ted Elliott and Terry Rossio were hired to write the script.
In July 1994  Jan de Bont was announced as the director.
Principal photography began in May 1997 and ended in September 1997.
Despite turning a profit  it was considered a box office disappointment.
Planned sequels were cancelled and an animated series was produced instead.

Suspecting a nest somewhere in the city  they cooperate with Nick to trace and destroy it.
After colliding with torpedoes  Godzilla sinks  believed to be dead by the authorities.

Godzilla dies from its wounds  and the remaining citizens and authorities celebrate.

Bad governance collectively encompasses governance in government and corporate settings.
It is the opposite of good governance.
Weak accountability in turn causes a distrust between the two parties and can lead to instability.
This distrust and uncertainty creates an unfavourable relationship between the parties.

Corruption occurs in many sectors ranging from political to economic environments.
Corruption can occur in many different ways and forms.

The Government runs under the framework established by the Constitution of Japan  adopted in 1947.
His role is ceremonial and he has no powers related to Government.
Its members are directly elected by the people  who are the source of sovereignty.
It is defined as the supreme organ of sovereignty in the Constitution.
They are independent from the executive and the legislative branches.
This event restored the country to Imperial rule and the proclamation of the Empire of Japan.
He is defined by the Constitution to be  the symbol of the State and of the unity of the people .
Performance of ceremonial functions.The Emperor is known to hold the nominal ceremonial authority.
One such example can be prominently seen in the 2009 Dissolution of the House of Representatives.
Emperor Jimmu was the first Emperor of Japan and the ancestor of all of the Emperors that followed.
He was officially enthroned on May 1  2019  following the abdication of his father.
He is styled as His Imperial Majesty  天皇陛下   and his reign bears the era name of Reiwa  令和 .
Fumihito is the heir presumptive to the Chrysanthemum Throne.
Executive    The Executive branch of Japan is headed by the Prime Minister.
The Prime Minister must also be both a civilian and a member of either house of the Diet.
However  it shall obtain prior or  depending on circumstances  subsequent approval of the Diet.
Prepare the budget  and present it to the Diet.
Enact cabinet orders in order to execute the provisions of this Constitution and of the law.
However  it cannot include penal provisions in such cabinet orders unless authorized by such law.
It reviews government expenditures and submits an annual report to the Diet.
Legislative     The Legislative branch organ of Japan is the National Diet  国会 .
The Diet is also able to impeach Court judges convicted of criminal or irregular conduct.
Speeches  debates  and votes cast in the Diet also enjoy parliamentary privileges.
During an election  only the House of Representatives is dissolved.
As of November 18  2017  it has 465 members.
233 seats are required for majority.
It can  however  be dissolved by the Prime Minister at will.
This includes the legislation of treaties  the budget  and the selection of the Prime Minister.
The document is taken to the Chamber for preparation by the General Secretary.
The General Secretary prepares the document for reading by the Speaker.
The Speaker of the House of Representatives promptly declares the dissolution of the House.
As of November 18  2017  it has 242 members.
The House of Councillors cannot be dissolved by the Prime Minister.
Penal system     The Penal system of Japan  矯正施設  is operated by the Ministry of Justice.
The main law that defines them is the Local Autonomy Law.
They are given limited executive and legislative powers by the Constitution.
Governors  mayors and members of assemblies are constitutionally elected by the residents.
There are self governing towns outside the cities as well as precincts of urban wards.
Like the cities  each has its own elected mayor and assembly.
Villages are the smallest self governing entities in rural areas.
Villages have mayors and councils elected to four year terms.
Governors are subject to recall referenda.
Candidates must be Japanese citizens and at least 30 years old.

Green is the color between blue and yellow on the visible spectrum.

It also has a long historical tradition as the color of Ireland and of Gaelic culture.

Han characters    are logograms developed for the writing of Chinese.
Chinese characters are the oldest continuously used system of writing in the world.
There are various national standard lists of characters  forms  and pronunciations.
A character almost always corresponds to a single syllable that is also a morpheme.
Cognates in the several varieties of Chinese are generally written with the same character.
Words have also been created by adding affixes  reduplication and borrowing from other languages.
Polysyllabic words are generally written with one character per syllable.
For the 500 most common characters  the proportion rises to 30 .
Often these readings are similar in sound and related in meaning.
In many cases the pronunciations diverged due to subsequent sound change.
For example   传 傳 has readings OC  drjon   MC drjwen    Mod.
chuán  to transmit  and  drjons   drjwenH   zhuàn  a record .
Middle Chinese forms are given in Baxter s transcription  in which H denotes the departing tone.
磨 has readings  maj   ma   mó  to grind  and  majs   maH   mò  grindstone .
For example   见 見 has readings  kens   kenH   jiàn  to see  and  gens   henH   xiàn  to appear .
败 敗 has readings  prats   pæjH   bài  to defeat  and  brats   bæjH   bài  to be defeated .
折 has readings  tjat   tsyet   zhé  to bend  and  djat   dzyet   shé  to break by bending .
Examples of pictograms include 日 rì for  sun   月 yuè for  moon   and 木 mù for  tree  or  wood .

The semantic component suggests the general meaning of the compound character.
The  phonetic component suggests the pronunciation of the compound character.

Genkan      One characteristic of a Japanese home is the genkan  or entryway.
As they take off their shoes  people step up onto a raised floor.
They point the tips of their shoes to the outside.
The rest of the residence is at the raised level of this floor.
Slippers for indoor use are usually placed there.

Washitsu      Many homes include at least one traditional Japanese styled room  or washitsu.
