Japan is divided into 47 administrative prefectures and eight traditional regions.
In 1937  Japan invaded China  in 1941  it entered World War II as an Axis power.
The characters 日本 mean  sun origin .
Clay vessels from the period are among the oldest surviving examples of pottery.
In 784  Emperor Kanmu moved the capital  settling on Heian kyō  modern Kyoto  in 794.
After Yoritomo s death  the Hōjō clan came to power as regents for the shōguns.
Go Daigo was defeated by Ashikaga Takauji in 1336  beginning the Muromachi period  1336–1573 .
When open war broke out  Ieyasu defeated rival clans in the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600.
The Edo period gave rise to kokugaku   national studies    the study of Japan by the Japanese.
Geography     Japan comprises 6852 islands extending along the Pacific coast of Asia.
The Ryukyu Islands  which include Okinawa  are a chain to the south of Kyushu.
The Nanpō Islands are south and east of the main islands of Japan.
Together they are often known as the Japanese archipelago.
As of 2019  Japan s territory is 377 975.24 km2  145 937.06 sq mi .
Japan has the sixth longest coastline in the world at 29 751 km  18 486 mi .
It has the 17th highest natural disaster risk as measured in the 2016 World Risk Index.
Japan has 111 active volcanoes.
In the summer  the region sometimes experiences extremely hot temperatures because of the foehn.
The Ryukyu and Nanpō Islands have a subtropical climate  with warm winters and hot summers.
Precipitation is very heavy  especially during the rainy season.
The main rainy season begins in early May in Okinawa  and the rain front gradually moves north.
In late summer and early autumn  typhoons often bring heavy rain.
Responding to rising concern  the government introduced environmental protection laws in 1970.
Japan is the world s fifth largest emitter of carbon dioxide.
In 2020 the government of Japan announced a target of carbon neutrality by 2050.
Japan s legislative organ is the National Diet  a bicameral parliament.
The Constitution of Japan  adopted in 1947  is the oldest unamended constitution in the world.
The main body of Japanese statutory law is called the Six Codes.
Military      Japan is the second highest ranked Asian country in the Global Peace Index 2020.
Japan maintains one of the largest military budgets of any country in the world.
As of 2019  Japan s labor force consisted of 67 million workers.
Japan has a low unemployment rate of around 2.4 percent.
Around 16 percent of the population were below the poverty line in 2017.
Its main exports are motor vehicles  iron and steel products  semiconductors and auto parts.
Japan ranks highly for competitiveness and economic freedom.
It is ranked sixth in the Global Competitiveness Report for 2015–2016.
Only 11.5  of Japan s land is suitable for cultivation.
Because of this lack of arable land  a system of terraces is used to farm in small areas.
Japan s small agricultural sector is highly subsidized and protected.
Japan has sparked controversy by supporting commercial whaling.
Japan s industrial sector makes up approximately 27.5  of its GDP.
For inbound tourism  Japan was ranked 11th in the world in 2019.
However  video gaming in Japan remains a major industry.
The space probe Akatsuki was launched in 2010 and achieved orbit around Venus in 2015.
Japan s plans in space exploration include building a moon base and landing astronauts by 2030.
The largest domestic airport  Haneda Airport in Tokyo  was Asia s second busiest airport in 2019.
Nuclear power was down from 11.2 percent in 2010.
Japan lacks significant domestic reserves and has a heavy dependence on imported energy.
Access to an improved water source is universal in Japan.
About 98  of the population receives piped water supply from public utilities.
In 2019  92  of the total Japanese population lived in cities.
The capital city Tokyo has a population of 13.8 million  2018 .
A growing number of younger Japanese are not marrying or remain childless.
Japan s population is expected to drop to around 100 million by 2050.
Today  1  to 1.5  of the population are Christians.
Almost all children continue their education at a three year senior high school.
The two top ranking universities in Japan are the University of Tokyo and Kyoto University.
Health      Health care is provided by national and local governments.
Another significant public health issue is smoking among Japanese men.
The Shrines of Ise have been celebrated as the prototype of Japanese architecture.
The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter is considered the oldest extant Japanese narrative.
In its literary forms  Japanese philosophy began about fourteen centuries ago.
Buddhism has profoundly impacted Japanese psychology  metaphysics  and esthetics.
Performing arts      Japanese music is eclectic and diverse.
Many instruments  such as the koto  were introduced in the 9th and 10th centuries.
Noh is one of the oldest continuous theater traditions in the world.
Isagiyosa  潔さ  is a virtue of the capability of accepting death with composure.
Cherry blossoms are a symbol of isagiyosa in the sense of embracing the transience of the world.
Seafood and Japanese rice or noodles are traditional staples.
Traditional Japanese sweets are known as wagashi.
Ingredients such as red bean paste and mochi are used.
Beer has been brewed in Japan since the late 17th century.
Japan is a world renowned powerhouse of animation.

Atmospheric control systems       The atmosphere on board the ISS is similar to that of Earth.

Geography     Japan comprises 6852 islands extending along the Pacific coast of Asia.
The Ryukyu Islands  which include Okinawa  are a chain to the south of Kyushu.
The Nanpō Islands are south and east of the main islands of Japan.
Together they are often known as the Japanese archipelago.
As of 2019  Japan s territory is 377 975.24 km2  145 937.06 sq mi .
Japan has the sixth longest coastline in the world at 29 751 km  18 486 mi .
It has the 17th highest natural disaster risk as measured in the 2016 World Risk Index.
Japan has 111 active volcanoes.
In the summer  the region sometimes experiences extremely hot temperatures because of the foehn.
The Ryukyu and Nanpō Islands have a subtropical climate  with warm winters and hot summers.
Precipitation is very heavy  especially during the rainy season.
The main rainy season begins in early May in Okinawa  and the rain front gradually moves north.
In late summer and early autumn  typhoons often bring heavy rain.

Japan s legislative organ is the National Diet  a bicameral parliament.
The Constitution of Japan  adopted in 1947  is the oldest unamended constitution in the world.
The main body of Japanese statutory law is called the Six Codes.

Brazil is home to the largest Japanese population outside Japan.

By the 1930s  Japanese industrialisation had significantly boosted the population.
However  prospects for Japanese people to migrate to other countries were limited.
About half of these immigrants came from southern Okinawa.

However   getting rich quick  was a dream that was almost impossible to achieve.

Soon  their debts became very significant.
The land owners in Brazil still had a slavery mentality.

Over the years  many Japanese managed to buy their own land and became small farmers.

Common temple features    Butsuden or Butsu dō  仏殿・仏堂  – lit.
Seems to have two stories  but has in fact only one and measures either 3x3 or 5x5 bays.
chinjusha  鎮守社 鎮主社  – a small shrine built at a Buddhist temple and dedicated to its tutelary kami.
chūmon  中門  – in a temple  the gate after the naindaimon connected to a kairō.
The prefix can be the name of a deity associated with it  e.g.
Yakushi dō  or Yakushi hall  or express the building s function within the temple s compound  e.g.
A building dedicated to lectures by the chief priest on Buddhism s scriptures  the hō .
hōjō  方丈  – the living quarters of the head priest of a Zen temple.
In Tendai Buddhism  a hall whose layout allows walking around a statue for meditation.
The purpose of walking is to concentrate on the Hokekyō and seek the ultimate truth.
kairō  回廊・廻廊  – a long and roofed portico like passage connecting two buildings.
Jōdo sect temples often call it miei dō.
golden hall   it is the main hall of a garan  housing the main object of worship.
It used to face the shōrō and lie next to the kō dō  but now the drum is usually kept in the rōmon.
kuri  庫裏  – see kuin kyō dō  経堂  – see kyōzō.
mi dō  御堂  – a generic honorific term for a building which enshrines a sacred statue.
Miroku Nyorai  弥勒如来  – Japanese name of Maitreya.
mon  門  – a temple s gate  which can be named after its position  nandaimon  lit.
The same gate can therefore be described using more than one term.
For example  a Niōmon can at the same time be a nijūmon.
nandaimon  南大門  – the main southern gate of a temple  in particular that at Nara s Tōdai ji.
nijūmon  二重門  – a two storied gate with a roof surrounding the first floor.
Niōmon  仁王門 or 二王門  – a two storied or high gate guarded by two wooden guardians called Niō.
noborirō  登廊  – a covered stairway at Nara s Hasedera.
sai dō  斎堂  – the refectory at a Zen temple or monastery.
sandō （参道）  the approach leading from a torii to a shrine.
The term is also used sometimes at Buddhist temples too.
sanmon  三門 or 山門  – the gate in front of the butsuden.
The name is short for Sangedatsumon  三解脱門   lit.
Its size depends on the temple s rank.
sekitō  石塔  – a stone pagoda  stupa .
In practice  shichidō garan can also mean simply a large complex.
shōrō  鐘楼  – a temple s belfry  a building from which a bell is hung.
sōbō  僧坊  – The monks  living quarters in a non Zen garan sō dō  僧堂  – Lit.
It used to be dedicated to many kinds of activities  from eating to sleeping  centered on zazen.
sōmon  総門  – the gate at the entrance of a temple.
It precedes the bigger and more important sanmon.
Strips of wood left behind tombs during annual ceremonies  tsuizen  symbolizing a stupa.
In present day Japanese  sotoba usually has this meaning.
Later  it became a subsidiary temple or a minor temple depending from a larger one.
Finally  it became also subsidiary temple being the family temple  bodaiji  of an important family.
Shrines of various size can be found next to  or inside temples.
tōrō  灯籠  – a lantern at a shrine or Buddhist temple.
Some of its forms are influenced by the gorintō.
tō  塔  A pagoda  and an evolution of the stupa.
tōsu or tōshi  東司  – a Zen monastery s toilet.
Yakushi dō  薬師堂  – a building that enshrines a statue of Yakushi Nyorai.
yokushitsu   浴室  – a monastery s bathroom.

The Japanese addressing system is used to identify a specific location in Japan.
Following the prefecture is the municipality.
For a large municipality this is the city  shi  市 .
In Japan  a city is separate from districts  which contain towns and villages.
There are also some municipalities like Ryūgasaki  Ibaraki which do not use any subdivisions.
Below this level  two styles of addressing are possible.
Building 10 in block 5 would be formally written as 5番10号  5 ban 10 gō .
This can be written as any of 3番地5  3 banchi 5   3番地の5  3 banchi no 5  or 3番5  3 ban 5 .
The apartment number may also be appended  resulting in 4 5 10 103.
In fact  many businesses have maps on their literature and business cards.
In addition to the address itself  all locations in Japan have a postal code.
A postal mark  〒  may precede the code to indicate that the number following is a postal code.
This system is  however  recognized by the post office and by government agencies.
For added precision  the street based address can be given  followed by the chō and land number.
While they continue to be used locally  e.g.
These function similarly to chōme and are treated as such in addresses.

Iki     Iki  いき  often written 粋  is a traditional aesthetic ideal in Japan.
Iki is an expression of simplicity  sophistication  spontaneity  and originality.
It is ephemeral  straightforward  measured  and unselfconscious.
Iki is not overly refined  pretentious  complicated.
Iki may signify a personal trait  or artificial phenomena exhibiting human will or consciousness.
The tasteful manifestation of sensuality can be iki.
Etymologically  iki has a root that means pure and unadulterated.
However  it also carries a connotation of having an appetite for life.
Yūgen     Yūgen  幽玄  is an important concept in traditional Japanese aesthetics.
The exact translation of the word depends on the context.
Yūgen suggests that which is beyond what can be said  but it is not an allusion to another world.
It is about this world  this experience.
All of these are portals to yūgen    To watch the sun sink behind a flower clad hill.
To wander on in a huge forest without thought of return.
To stand upon the shore and gaze after a boat that disappears behind distant islands.
To contemplate the flight of wild geese seen and lost among the clouds.

Aesthetic concepts     Japanese art is characterized by unique polarities.

Modesty and unconventional things are what are seen as the sabi sabi aesthetic.

Sabi is beauty and how it originates from age.
Wabi sabi has always been related to tea ceremonies in Japanese culture.

Wabi sabi is also related to activities such as architecture  fashion  and philosophy.
While this is true  there are many who wish to keep the belief alive despite what others believe.
Overall  wabi sabi seems to be a very mindful approach to everyday life.
A calm way to see things  and a way to live without coming off as judgmental.
When understanding wabi sabi  there are terms that strongly relate to the aesthetic as well.
Yugen  subtly profound grace  not obvious.
Miyabi      In the ongoing history of Japan  miyabi can stand for many things.
For this  it is one of the older aesthetics among most of the Japanese aesthetics in the culture.
That would explain why it is not as popular as the rest which may be newer compared to miyabi.
It is a term that is also used to express aristocratic culture.
Miyabi eliminates all forms of rudeness and crudity from the culture.
This brings about the proper picture and form of aristocratic culture.
Miyabi brings about these changes.
Shibui      Shibui is coming to understand an object or an art piece for what it is.
In many ways  shibui is very similar to wabi sabi but is not wabi sabi.
Shibui appreciates items and objects for simply being.
There is no complication or irrational thinking when it comes down to shibui.
Both these terms relate to subtle  unobtrusive beauty.
Direct and simple is the way of shibui.
It is used in different art forms in Japan even still today.
Almost akin to how a story is told.

History     Rice is a staple in Japanese cuisine.
Wheat and soybeans were introduced shortly after rice.
During the Kofun period  Buddhism became the official religion of the country.
Therefore  eating meat and fish was prohibited.
In 675 AD  Emperor Tenmu prohibited the eating of horses  dogs  monkeys  and chickens.
In the 8th and 9th centuries  many emperors continued to prohibit killing many types of animals.
During this period  chopsticks were introduced to Japan.
Initially  they were only used by the nobility.
The general population used their hands  as utensils were quite expensive.
Spices were rare to find at the time.
Spices like pepper and garlic were only used in a minimalist amount.
In the absence of meat  fish was served as the main protein  as Japan is an island nation.
Fish has influenced many iconic Japanese dishes today.
In the 9th century  grilled fish and sliced raw fish were widely popular.
Sushi thus became a popular snack food and main entrée  combining fish with rice.
During the Edo period  mid 15th century   sushi without fermentation was introduced.

After this New Years feast  the general population from Japan started to consume meat again.

Iki     Iki  いき  often written 粋  is a traditional aesthetic ideal in Japan.
Iki is an expression of simplicity  sophistication  spontaneity  and originality.
It is ephemeral  straightforward  measured  and unselfconscious.
Iki is not overly refined  pretentious  complicated.
Iki may signify a personal trait  or artificial phenomena exhibiting human will or consciousness.
The tasteful manifestation of sensuality can be iki.
Etymologically  iki has a root that means pure and unadulterated.
However  it also carries a connotation of having an appetite for life.
Yūgen     Yūgen  幽玄  is an important concept in traditional Japanese aesthetics.
The exact translation of the word depends on the context.
Yūgen suggests that which is beyond what can be said  but it is not an allusion to another world.
It is about this world  this experience.

Japanese giant salamanders are widespread across rivers in southwestern Japan.
The largest wild specimen on record weighed 58 lb  26.3 kg  and was 4.46 ft  136 cm  long.
It has very small eyes with no eyelids and poor eye sight.
Its mouth extends across the width of its head  and can open to the width of its body.A.
Behavior     The Japanese giant salamander is restricted to streams with clear  cool water.
Due to its large size and lack of gills  it is confined to flowing water where oxygen is abundant.
it is entirely aquatic and almost entirely nocturnal.
This feature is essential for hunting prey due to its poor eyesight.
It feeds mainly on insects  frogs and fish.
It has a very slow metabolism and can sometimes go for weeks without eating.
In the wild  it may live for nearly 80 years.
Lifecycle     The Japanese giant salamander remains in bodies of water its entire life.
Large males guard a den and are known as denmasters.
They mate with several females throughout the season.
Smaller males who do not have a den may attempt to enter the den and fertilize some of the eggs.
The male releases milt over the eggs laid by the female.
The larvae then develop gills and limbs  then lose their gills once they metamorphose into adults.
The species was designated as a special natural monument in 1951  and is federally protected.
River disturbance has led to fewer appropriate nesting sites and dams block migration paths.
It is considered Near Threatened by IUCN  and is included on CITES Appendix I.
It can be found on the islands of Kyushu  Honshu  and Shikoku in Japan.

Lacquer was used in Japan as early as 7000 BCE  during the Jōmon period.
They learned to refine urushi  poison oak sap  – the process taking several months.
Iron oxide  colcothar  and cinnabar  mercury sulfide  were used for producing red lacquer.
Lacquer was used both on pottery  and on different types of wooden items.
In some cases  burial clothes for the dead were also lacquered.
The shrine is made of lacquered hinoki or Japanese cypress and camphor wood  both native species.
This made it possible to make the gold and silver of lacquerware brighter than before.
Togidashi maki e  a kind of maki e  was developed and completed in this period.
In the 18th century colored lacquers came into wider use.
Foremost among these was Shibata Zeshin  who has been called  Japan s greatest lacquerer .
He placed lacquer panels in frames  imitating Western oil paintings.
This style could be produced more quickly and cheaply than traditional lacquers.
This is due to the Japanese government s policy of local revitalization.
An object is formed from wood  sometimes leather  paper  or basketry.
Lacquer is applied to seal and protect the object  and then decoration is added.
The application of gold powder is known as maki e  and is a very common decorative element.
iro urushi  色漆   literally  color lacquer   was created by adding pigments to clear lacquer.
This method became popular in the 17th century in Takayama  Hida province.
Many articles for use in tea drinking were manufactured using this technique.
Negoro lacquerwares were produced at the Negoro ji temple complex in Izumi province.
This effect has since been copied and emulated elsewhere.
Silver or gold foil is used as well  and sealed under a layer of transparent lacquer.
Wajima nuri  輪島塗  can be dated back to late 15th century from Wajima  Ishikawa Prefecture.
Many of them are Buddhist items  dating from the Heian period.
See List of National Treasures of Japan  crafts others .

Little is known of the language s prehistory  or when it first appeared in Japan.
Sentence final particles are used to add emotional or emphatic impact  or make questions.
Nouns have no grammatical number or gender  and there are no articles.
Verbs are conjugated  primarily for tense and voice  but not person.
Japanese equivalents of adjectives are also conjugated.
Very little is known about the Japanese of this period.
Old Japanese      Old Japanese is the oldest attested stage of the Japanese language.
Through the spread of Buddhism  the Chinese writing system was imported to Japan.
The end of Old Japanese coincides with the end of the Nara period in 794.
Based on the Man yōgana system  Old Japanese can be reconstructed as having 88 distinct syllables.
The Kojiki has 88  but all later texts have 87.
The distinction between mo1 and mo2 apparently was lost immediately following its composition.
Man yōgana also has a symbol for  je   which merges with  e  before the end of the period.
kwa  and palatalised  kya  consonants are added.
Intervocalic  ɸ  merges with  w  by the 11th century.
Early Modern Japanese gradually evolved into Modern Japanese during the 19th century.
As a result  many elderly people in these countries can still speak Japanese.
The meanings of the two terms are almost the same.
Hyōjungo or kyōtsūgo is a conception that forms the counterpart of dialect.
Hyōjungo is taught in schools and used on television and in official communications.
It is the version of Japanese discussed in this article.
The two systems have different rules of grammar and some variance in vocabulary.
Dialects      Dozens of dialects are spoken in Japan.
Some even differ in vowel and consonant inventories  although this is uncommon.
Within each type are several subdivisions.
Dialects of Tōhoku and North Kantō are associated with typical farmers.
The imperial court also seems to have spoken an unusual variant of the Japanese of the time.
Young people mostly use Japanese and cannot understand the Ryukyuan languages.
Okinawan Japanese is a variant of Standard Japanese influenced by the Ryukyuan languages.
As it stands  only the link to Ryukyuan has wide support.
However  some of these allophones have since become phonemic.
This type of cluster only occurs in onsets.
Consonant length  gemination  is also phonemic.
The stresses differentiate the words.
The basic sentence structure is topic–comment.
For example  Kochira wa Tanaka san desu  こちらは田中さんです .
kochira   this   is the topic of the sentence  indicated by the particle  wa.
As a phrase  Tanaka san desu is the comment.
This sentence literally translates to  As for this person   it  is Mr. Ms.
The topic is zō  elephant   and the subject is hana  nose .
In Japanese  the subject or object of a sentence need not be stated if it is obvious from context.
A single verb can be a complete sentence  Yatta!
I   we   they   etc  did  it ! .
For instance  one does not say in English   The amazed he ran down the street.
Japanese often use titles of the person referred to where pronouns would be used in English.
人人  hitobito  usually written with an iteration mark as 人々 .
Words for people are usually understood as singular.
Thus Tanaka san usually means Mr. Ms.
A group described as Tanaka san tachi may include people not named Tanaka.
For others that represent a change of state  the  te iru form indicates a perfect aspect.
For example  kite iru means  He has come  and is still here    but tabete iru means  He is eating .
In the formal register  the question particle  ka is added.
For example  ii desu  いいです   It is OK  becomes ii desu ka  いいですか。   Is it OK? .
Negatives are formed by inflecting the verb.
Plain negative forms are i adjectives  see below  and inflect as such  e.g.
Pan o tabenakatta  パンを食べなかった。   I did not eat bread .
The word da  plain   desu  polite  is the copula verb.
This comes into use because only i adjectives and verbs can carry tense in Japanese.
For example  Neko ga iru  There s a cat   Ii kangae ga nai   I  haven t got a good idea .
and has been productive in creating modern slang words.
tobidasu  to fly out  to flee   from tobu  to fly  to jump    dasu  to put out  to emit  .
形容動詞 keiyōdōshi  or na adjectives  which are followed by a form of the copula  usually na.
For example  hen  strange  変なひと hen na hito  a strange person .
Examples include ookina  big   kono  this   iwayuru  so called  and taishita  amazing .
The grammatical function of nouns is indicated by postpositions  also called particles.
These include for example   が ga for the nominative case.彼がやった。Kare ga yatta.
に ni for the dative case.田中さんにあげて下さい。 Tanaka san ni agete kudasai  Please give it to Mr.
It is also used for the lative case  indicating a motion to a location.
日本に行きたい。 Nihon ni ikitai  I want to go to Japan.
However  へ e is more commonly used for the lative case.パーティーへ行かないか。 pātī e ikanai ka?
を o for the accusative case.何を食べますか。 Nani o tabemasu ka?
literally   As for me  sushi is good.
As for Mr. Ikeda  he is forty two years old.
Others in the group may also be of that age.
Absence of wa often means the subject is the focus of the sentence.
It is Mr. Ikeda who is forty two years old.
Strangers will also speak to each other politely.
For example  the  san suffix   Mr   Mrs.  or  Miss   is an example of honorific language.
Most nouns in the Japanese language may be made polite by the addition of o  or go  as a prefix.
Such a construction often indicates deference to either the item s owner or to the object itself.
Most Japanese people employ politeness to indicate a lack of familiarity.
This occurs regardless of age  social class  or gender.
A small number of words have come into Japanese from the Ainu language.
Words of different origins occupy different registers in Japanese.
Today most borrowings are from English.
This is when the history of Japanese as a written language begins in its own right.
Over time  a writing system evolved.
However  because of hiragana s accessibility  more and more people began using it.
Japanese students begin to learn kanji from their first year at elementary school.
As for kanji for personal names  the circumstances are somewhat complicated.
Names containing unapproved characters are denied registration.
For this reason  hiragana are appended to kanji to show verb and adjective conjugations.
Hiragana used in this way are called okurigana.
The JLPT is offered twice a year.
Indian literature also had an influence through the spread of Buddhism in Japan.
The earliest literary works in Japan were created in the Nara period.
One of the stories they describe is the tale of Urashima Tarō.
During this era  literature became centered on a cultural elite of nobility and monks.
Editing the resulting anthologies of poetry soon became a national pastime.
The volumes cover various tales from India  China and Japan.
Many literary works were marked by a nostalgia for the Heian period.
Notable examples of travel diaries include Fuji kikō  1432  and Tsukushi michi no ki  1480 .
Ihara s Life of an Amorous Man is considered the first work in this genre.
He made his life s work the transformation of haikai into a literary genre.
Fukuda Chiyo ni  1703–1775  is widely regarded as one of the greatest haiku poets.
Before her time  haiku by women were often dismissed and ignored.
While still a teenager  she had already become very popular all over Japan for her poetry.

As a full blown translation from a Western language  it was the first of its kind in Japan.
The introduction of European literature brought free verse into the poetic repertoire.
It became widely used for longer works embodying new intellectual themes.

Physical characteristics     The Japanese macaque is sexually dimorphic.
Males weigh on average 11.3 kg  25 lb   while females average 8.4 kg  19 lb .
Macaques from colder areas tend to weigh more than ones from warmer areas.
Male average height is 57.01 cm  22.44 in  and female average height is 52.28 cm  20.58 in .
Their brain size is about 95 g  3.4 oz .
The macaque has a pinkish face and posterior.
The rest of its body is covered in brown or greyish hair.
The macaque can cope with temperatures as low as −20 °C  −4 °F .Macaques mostly move on all fours.
They are also great swimmers and have been reported to swim over half a kilometer.
Macaque groups tend to contain a number of adults of both sexes.
In addition  a Japanese macaque troop contains several matrilines.
However  many males spend ample time away from any group and may leave and join several groups.
Males within a group have a dominance hierarchy  with one male having alpha status.
The dominance status of male macaques usually changes when a former alpha male leaves or dies.
The longer a male is in a troop  the higher his status is likely to be.
Females also exist in a stable dominance hierarchy  and a female s rank depends on her mother.
Younger females tend to rank higher than their older siblings.
Higher ranking matrilines have greater social cohesion.
Females which are matrilineally related groom each other more often than unrelated individuals.
Females enter into consortships with an average of four males a season.
Higher ranking males have longer consortships than their subordinates.
In addition  higher ranking males try to disrupt consortships of lower ranking males.
Females attempt to mate with males of any rank.
However  dominant males mate more as they are more successful in mate guarding.
The female decides whether mating takes place.
In addition  dominance does not mean a male will successfully mate with a female.
Males may also temporarily join another troop during the mating season and mate with the females.
Females also engage in same sex mounting.
In addition  females  faces and anogenital regions turn scarlet.
A female emits a  squawk    squeak   or produces an atonal  cackle  during copulation.
Males have no copulatory vocalizations.
Macaques usually give birth on the ground.
Infants are born with dark brown hair.
A mother carries her infant on her belly for its first four weeks.
After this time  the mother carries her infant on her back  as well.
Infants continue to be carried past a year.
In some populations  male infants tend to play in larger groups more often than females.
However  female infants have more social interaction than their male counterparts.
Males prefer to associate with other males around the same age when they are two years old.
Female infants will associate with individuals of all ages and sexes.
Communication     During feeding or moving  Japanese macaques often emit  coos .
These most likely serve to keep the troop together and strengthen social relations between females.
Macaques usually respond to coos with coos of their own.
Coos are also uttered before grooming along with  girney  calls.
Variants of the  girney  call are made in different contexts.
This call also serves as appeasement between individuals in aggressive encounters.
Intelligence and culture      The Japanese macaque is an intelligent species.
After a while  others started to copy her behavior.
Ecology    The Japanese macaque is diurnal.
In colder areas  from autumn to early winter  macaques feed in between different activities.
In the winter  macaques have two to four feeding bouts each day with fewer daily activities.
In the spring and summer  they have two or three bouts of feeding daily.
In warmer areas such as Yakushima  daily activities are more varied.
During the winter  macaques huddle together for warmth in sleeping grounds.
Diet      The Japanese macaque is omnivorous and eats a variety of foods.
Over 213 species of plants are included on the macaque s diet.
It also eats insects  bark  and soil.
On Yakushima Island  fruit  mature leaves  and fallen seeds are primarily eaten.
The macaque also eats fungi  ferns  invertebrates  and other parts of plants.
Distribution and habitat    The Japanese macaque is the northernmost living nonhuman primate.
It is found on three of the four main Japanese islands  Honshu  Shikoku  and Kyushu.
The northernmost populations live on the Shimokita Peninsula  the northernmost point of Honshu.
Several of Japan s smaller islands are also inhabited by macaques.
At first  many perished in the unfamiliar habitat  which consists of arid brushland.
The macaques flourished  and by 1995  the troop consisted of 500 to 600 individuals.
The replacement of natural forest with lumber plantations is the most serious threat.

Japanese martial arts refer to the variety of martial arts native to the country of Japan.
The terms bujutsu and bugei have different meanings from budo  at least historically speaking.
The history of Japan is somewhat unusual in its relative isolation.
Nevertheless  the teaching and training of these martial arts did evolve.
However  what it means for an art to be either  traditional  or  modern  is subject to some debate.
As a rule of thumb  the primary purpose of a koryū martial art was for use in war.
Jujutsu      Jujutsu  柔術 じゅうじゅつ  jūjutsu   literally translates to  Soft Skills .
Defensive tactics included blocking  evading  off balancing  blending and escaping.
For this reason  they include extensive use of atemi waza  vital striking technique .
These tactics would be of little use against an armored opponent on a battlefield.
In Japan  the use of the katana is no different.
This development of the sword is paralleled by the development of the methods used to wield it.
During times of peace  the warriors trained with the sword  and invented new ways to implement it.
During war  these theories were tested.
The terminology used in Japanese swordsmanship is somewhat ambiguous.
Many names have been used for various aspects of the art or to encompass the art as a whole.
Kenjutsu       Kenjutsu  剣術 けんじゅつ  literally means  the art science of the sword .
The term came into use specifically during the Warring States Period  15th–17th centuries .
However  many koryu maintain naginatajutsu in their curriculum.
Also of note  during the late Edo period  naginata were used to train women and ladies in waiting.
Sōjutsu      Sōjutsu  槍術 そうじゅつ  is the Japanese art of fighting with the spear  yari .
For most of Japan s history  sōjutsu was practiced extensively by traditional schools.
In times of war  it was a primary skill of many soldiers.
Today it is a minor art taught in very few schools.
Other arts existed to teach military skills other than the use of weaponry.
Additionally  many of the gendai budō have included a sporting element to them.
Judo and  kendo are both examples of this.
Judo was created by Kano Jigoro  嘉納 治五郎 Kanō Jigorō  1860–1938  at the end of the 19th century.
Judo became an Olympic sport in 1964  and has spread throughout the world.
Aikido      Aikido  合氣道 あいきどう  aikidō  means  the way to harmony with ki .
It is a Japanese martial art developed by Morihei Ueshiba  植芝 盛平 Ueshiba Morihei  1883 – 1969 .
Archers were also used in sieges and sea battles.
Karate      Karate  空手  karate  literally means  empty hand .
It is also sometimes called  the way of the empty hand   空手道  karatedō .
It was originally called 唐手   Chinese hand    also pronounced  karate .
Karate is a fusion of pre existing Okinawan martial arts  called  te   and Chinese martial arts.
As a result  karate training was subsequently incorporated into Japan s public school system.
Many karate practitioners also participate in light  and no contact competitions while some  ex.
kyokushin karate  still compete in full contact competitions with little or no protective gear.
Japan Railways  it subsequently became popular in many other countries.
Generally  it is the principle of matching your opponent in order to defeat him.
One may  match  the opponent in a clash of force  possibly even resulting in a mutual kill.
Literally translating as  heart   in context it can also mean  character  or  attitude.
Gichin Funakoshi       Budō      Literally  martial way  is the Japanese term for martial art.
It emphasizes courage  bravery  and loyalty to their lord  daimyō  above all.
It is of prime importance not only in karate but in all modern martial arts.
He who would follow the way of karate must be courteous  not only in training but in daily life.
While humble and gentle  he should never be servile.
His performance of the kata should reflect boldness and confidence.
This seemingly paradoxical combination of boldness and gentleness leads ultimately to harmony.
One is the hard method  剛法  gōhō   and the other is the soft method  柔法  jūhō .
The hard method is characterized by the direct application of counter force to an opposing force.
Hard method techniques are generally conceptualized as being linear.
Soft method techniques are generally conceptualized as being circular.
Openings  隙  suki  are the foundation of a successful attack.
Each type of initiative complements the other  and has different advantages and weaknesses.
For example  a faster opponent s maai is farther away than a slower opponent.
Shuhari     The principle of Shuhari describes the three stages of learning.
Sōke  宗家 そうけ  translates as  headmaster  meaning the head of a ryu.
It has become part of the teaching process in Japanese martial arts schools.
The older system  usual prior to 1868  was based a series of licenses or menkyo.
Forms      It has often been said that forms  kata  are the backbone of the martial arts.
Nevertheless  different schools and styles put a varying amount of emphasis upon their practice.

Shinto and Buddhist traditions are the cornerstones of Japanese mythology.
The child s corpse creates even more gods.
After spending so much time in Yomi  Izanagi cleansed himself with a purification ceremony.
As Izanagi cleansed himself  the water and robes that fell from his body created many more gods.
Myths related the Sun  the Moon  and the Storm kami are full of strife and conflict.
Meanwhile  the sun goddess and the storm god Susanoo s conflicts were intense and bloody.
The sun goddess Amaterasu s importance in Japanese mythology is two fold.
Emperor Jimmu is considered to be the human descendant of Amaterasu the Sun goddess.
His ascension to the throne marked the  Transition from Age of the Gods to Human Age .
One example of a kami who looks almost human in depictions is the ruler of the Seas Ryujin.
It is important to note that Shintoism is still practiced today in Japan.

Christianity was banned in Japan until well into the nineteenth century.

Before the government formalized the naming system in 1868  Japanese personal names were fluid.

Prior to Emperor Jomei  the imina of the emperors were very long and not used.

Noodles are a staple of Japanese cuisine.
They are often served chilled with dipping sauces  or in soups or hot dishes.
The dough is risen before being rolled.
They were imported from China during the Meiji period.
The noodles may vary in shape  width  and length.
These noodles are chewy or rubbery.
Shirataki are used to add texture to dishes such as sukiyaki and oden.
Soba is a noodle made from buckwheat and wheat flour.
Soba noodles are available dried or fresh.
They may be served  with hot broth or cold with dipping sauce  tsuyu .
Sōmen requires oil in its manufacture.
These noodles are often served in the same manner as sōmen and udon noodles.
While they are mostly white  there are bundles mixed with noodles of pinkish or brown hues.
Udon are the thickest of the noodles served in Japanese Cuisine.
Udon are white  wheat based noodles  that are 4 6mm in width.
Udon dishes include kitsune udon  Nabeyaki udon  curry udon  and yaki udon.
However  sara udon is made using a different kind of noodle which is crispy.
Harusame are glass noodles made from potato starch.
Tokoroten are jelly like slices of Agar with a rectangular cross section.

Tanka is a name for and a type of poem found in the Man yōshū  used for shorter poems.

Roei style waka      Roei was a favored style of reciting poetical works at that time.
It was a way of reciting in voice  with relatively slow and long tones.
Fujiwara no Kintō  966–1041  compiled Wakan rōeishū   Sino Japanese Anthology for Rōei   ca.
1013  from Japanese and Chinese poetry works written for roei.
In ancient times  it was a custom for kuge to exchange waka instead of letters in prose.
Sometimes improvised waka were used in daily conversation in high society.
In particular  the exchange of waka was common between lovers.
Soon  writing and reciting Waka became a part of aristocratic culture.
People recited a piece of appropriate waka freely to imply something on an occasion.
Uta awase  ceremonial waka recitation contests  developed in the middle of the Heian period.
The team with the higher overall score won the contest.
Both winning poet and team received a certain prize.
Holding Uta awase was expensive and possible only for Emperors or very high ranked kuge.
The size of Uta awase increased.
Uta awase were recorded with hundreds of rounds.
Uta awase motivated the refinement of waka technique but also made waka formalistic and artificial.
In the story most of those waka were created  as an exchange of letters or a conversation.
Many classic works of both waka and kanshi were quoted by the nobles.
Fujiwara no Teika had three lines of descendants  the Nijō  Reizei family and Kyōgoku family.

During this time the Fujiwara clan was also active both politically and poetically.
Imayō consists of four lines in 8–5  or 7–5  syllables.
Usually it was sung to the accompaniment of instrumental music and dancing.
Female dancers  shirabyōshi  danced to the accompaniment of imayō.

Waka in the period of cloistered rule      Some new trends appeared in waka.

Renga      Renga is a collaborative verse form between two or more poets.
Tsukubashū  the first imperial anthology of renga  was published in about 1356.
In Kyoto there were some artists who were simultaneously poets and painters.
Painters of the Shujo school were known as good poets.
Among such poet painters the most significant was Yosa Buson.
Buson began his career as a painter but went on to become a master of renku  too.
He left many paintings accompanied by his own haiku poems.
Such combination of haiku with painting is known as haiga.
Waka underwent a revival  too  in relation to kokugaku  the study of Japanese classics.

Haikai      Haikai emerged from the renga of the medieval period.
Matsuo Bashō was a noted proponent.

In the late Edo period  a master of haikai  Karai Senryū made an anthology.
His style became known as senryū  after his pseudonym.
Senryū is a style of satirical poetry whose motifs are taken from daily life in 5–7–5 syllables.

Japan has an exceptionally long and successful history of ceramic production.
Since the 4th century  Japanese ceramics have often been influenced by Chinese and Korean pottery.
In the 20th century  a modern ceramics industry  e.g.  Noritake and Toto Ltd.  grew up.
Japanese pottery is distinguished by two polarised aesthetic traditions.
Most raku ware  where the final decoration is partly random  is in this tradition.
The pottery was formed by coiling clay ropes and fired in an open fire.
Jōmon  Yayoi  and later Haji ware shared the firing process but had different styles of design.
Its manufacture began in the 5th century and continued in outlying areas until the 14th century.
Contemporary Haji ware and Haniwa funerary objects were earthenware like Yayoi.
Kamui ware appeared in this time  as well as Atsumi ware and Tokoname ware.
Among these  the Seto kiln in Owari Province  present day Aichi Prefecture  had a glaze technique.
The Seto kiln primarily imitated Chinese ceramics as a substitute for the Chinese product.
It developed various glazes  ash brown  iron black  feldspar white  and copper green.
Seto kiln also produced unglazed stoneware.
A number of Japanese monks who traveled to monasteries in China also brought pieces back home.
Japan also imported Chinese pottery as well as Korean and Vietnamese ceramics.
The Japanese also ordered custom designed ceramics from Chinese kilns.
The artist potter Hon ami Kōetsu made several tea bowls now considered masterpieces.
Soon the Satsuma  Hagi  Karatsu  Takatori  Agano and Arita kilns were begun.
Unlike Nabeshima ware  Hirado went on to be a significant exporter in the 19th century.
Their works were the models for later Kyōyaki.
Most of the works promoted internationally were in the decorative arts  including pottery.
These wares were highly praised in the West.
These artists won multiple awards at international exhibitions.
His work strongly influenced Western perceptions of Japanese design.
Its founding father was Yanagi Sōetsu  1889–1961 .
Most of the village wares were made anonymously by local potters for utilitarian purposes.
The modern potters operate in Shiga  Iga  Karatsu  Hagi  and Bizen.
Yamamoto Masao  Toushuu  of Bizen and Miwa Kyusetsu of Hagi were designated ningen kokuho.
1964  studied Leach and spent a number of years in Japan studying mingei style.
Clay    Clay is chosen largely based on local materials available.
There is an abundance of most basic types of clay in Japan.
Due to naturally occurring kaolin deposits  many porcelain clays are found in Kyushu.
Production methods     The earliest pieces were made by pressing the clay into shape.
Production by kneading and cutting slabs developed later  for example  for Haniwa clay figures.
Potter s wheel     The first use of the potter s wheel in Japan can be seen in Sue pottery.
From this beginning the two man wheel developed.
However  it is now difficult to find craftsmen who can make or repair them.
They are a traditional tool from Arita  Kyushu.
They can also be used to compress the bottoms of thrown forms.
tonbo –  dragonflies   are the functional equivalent of Western calipers with an added feature.
yumi – are wire and bamboo trimming harps that double as a fluting tool.
They are used to cut off uneven or torn rims as well as to facet leather hard forms.
The largest combs have about 20 teeth.
take bon bon – also not a throwing tool  but a Japanese slip trailer.
Wares    Hundreds of different wares and styles have existed throughout its history.
The most historic and well known ones have received recognition from the government.
For more information see the list of Japanese ceramics sites.
Museums and collections    A number of museums in Japan are dedicated entirely only to ceramics.
Most ceramic museums around the world have collections of Japanese pottery  many very extensive.
Japanese modern ceramic works are often very sought after and expensive.

Most rice in Japan is processed and consumed as white rice  the staple food of Japan.
Hatsuga genmai  発芽玄米  is brown rice that has been soaked in heated water until germinated.
It has a softer texture than ordinary brown rice and a pleasant fragrance.
It is sold in Japanese supermarkets  but it can also be made at home.
Some high end rice cookers have a GABA rice setting to automate the process.
It takes less time to cook than brown rice but retains more of the vitamins than white rice.
The rice polishing machines typically polish a 10 kg amount for 100 yen.
Most supermarkets in Japan sell ready polished rice in 10 kg  5 kg  and smaller bags.
It is used in sushi  寿司  and onigiri.
Plain rice is used in yōshoku dishes such as curry rice  omurice  and doria.
The rice is first washed to release excess starch.
Soaking times also depend on the quality and freshness of the rice.
After this  it is steamed until the centre of the rice becomes soft.
Prepared rice is usually served from the rice cooker into a chawan  or rice bowl.
After cooking  rice may also be held in a covered wooden box called an ohitsu.
This market ceased with economic controls in 1939.

Muromachi period and Sengoku period      Buddhist sculptures declined in quantity and quality.

Length      What generally differentiates the different swords is their length.
Japanese swords are measured in units of shaku.
However the historical shaku was slightly longer  13.96 inches or 35.45 cm .
A blade longer than one shaku but less than two is considered a shōtō  short sword .
The wakizashi and kodachi are in this category.
Most blades that fall into the  shōtō  size range are wakizashi.
However  some daitō were designed with blades slightly shorter than 2 shaku.
These were called kodachi and are somewhere in between a true daitō and a wakizashi.
A shōtō and a daitō together are called  a daishō  literally   big little  .
The daishō was the symbolic armament of the Edo period samurai.
A blade longer than two shaku is considered a daitō  or long sword.

History     The first documented evidence of tea in Japan dates to the 9th century.
By imperial order in 816  tea plantations began to be cultivated in the Kinki region of Japan.

This powdered green tea was first used in religious rituals in Buddhist monasteries.
Wabi  represents the inner  or spiritual  experiences of human lives.
Sabi   on the other hand  represents the outer  or material side of life.
Originally  it meant  worn    weathered   or  decayed .

Equipment     The equipment for tea ceremony is called chadōgu  茶道具 .
The chakin is a small rectangular white linen or hemp cloth mainly used to wipe the tea bowl.
Bowls are frequently named by their creators or owners  or by a tea master.
Bowls over four hundred years old are in use today  but only on unusually special occasions.
The best bowls are thrown by hand  and some bowls are extremely valuable.
They are used to scoop tea from the tea caddy into the tea bowl.
Bamboo tea scoops in the most casual style have a nodule in the approximate center.
Different styles and colours are used in various tea traditions.
This is the implement used to mix the powdered tea with the hot water.
Tea whisks are carved from a single piece of bamboo.
The guests are served a cup of the hot water  kombu tea  roasted barley tea  or sakurayu.
When the preparation of the utensils is complete  the host prepares thick tea.
Bows are exchanged between the host and the guest receiving the tea.
The guest then bows to the second guest  and raises the bowl in a gesture of respect to the host.
The host then rekindles the fire and adds more charcoal.
This examination is done to show respect and admiration for the host.
The host then collects the utensils  and the guests leave the tea house.
The host bows from the door  and the gathering is over.
The procedures performed in chadō are called  collectively  temae.
The act of performing these procedures during a chaji is called  doing temae .

Single episode  or  tanpatsu  dramas that are usually two hours in length are also broadcast.
The majority of dramas are aired weekdays in the evenings around 9pm through 11pm.
Structurally  Japanese dramas can be compared to American or British miniseries.
Many fans have even been able to visit their idols while shooting scenes as the show is airing.
The  trendy  formula was improved in the early 1990s  when the story lines changed with the times.
Even today  the success of Japanese dramas is a result of sticking with the trendy drama formula.
Many of these shows employ young actors who use them as springboards to bigger projects.
Fuji TV is widely known as the inventor of the drama formula.
Most modern  Getsuku  dramas have also abandoned the traditional love story format.
Other Japan television networks have their own focuses.
Most dramas will start off with one or two minutes of theme music during the opening credits.
Background music is placed and used at strategic points of the episode to set the mood.
Most television networks work with music companies to produce original soundtracks.
Closing themes are often sung by a popular J pop singer or band.
Most of the theme music heard in their taiga and asadora dramas were written and produced in house.
In recent years  many theme songs have been licensed from sources outside Japan.
When the Japanese drama is licensed outside Japan  theme music licensing becomes very costly.
Broadband is a complementary medium.
Television ratings are calculated by several researching firms.
Video Research Ltd. is one of the more reliable firms.
The ratings become available for the general public every Wednesday.
Rating system     The rating system is very simple.
The viewer count of a given episode is calculated using a variety of polling methods.
Ratings are calculated using a percentage or point system.
This is based on the episode s viewership numbers divided by the market size.
Finally  the numbers are published on the research firm s website.
There is no solid science on how to interpret these rating percentages.
For fans  simply the drama with the highest percentage is the  winner  for the week.
Finally  rating percentage plays a heavy role in the success of a drama artist.
A variation of the Mai style of Japanese dance is the Kyomai or Kyoto style dance.
Kyomai developed in the 17th century Tokugawa cultural period.
Dance genres     There are several types of traditional Japanese dance.
In Sagi Musume  The Heron Maiden  the dancer s role is the spirit of the heron.
In classical versions  the spirit assumes a handsome  strong pose at the end of the dance.
Kabuki        Kabuki  歌舞伎  is a classical Japanese dance drama.
Kabuki is therefore sometimes translated as  the art of singing and dancing .
These are  however  ateji characters which do not reflect actual etymology.
The kanji of  skill  generally refers to a performer in kabuki theatre.
During the Genroku era  kabuki thrived.
The structure of a kabuki play was formalized during this period  as were many elements of style.
Noh Mai      The origin of Noh mai can be traced back to as far as the thirteenth century.
Noh mai dances are put together by a series of forms.
Forms are patterns of body movements that are done elegantly and with beauty.
There are several types of Noh mai dances.
In otoko mai the performer does not wear a mask and is portraying the character as being heroic.
Another male dance is kami mai  where the dancer acts as though he is a deity.
The female version of this is called kagura and can be performed in various ways.
These are the six varieties that make up the Noh mai dance types.
Costumes are a major part of Noh theatre  including the Noh mai.
The most important part of the Noh costumes are the masks.
The Noh mai masks are thought to be the most artistic masks in Japan.
The masks are only worn by the main characters.
The masks have neutral expressions so it is the job of the actor to bring the character to life.
Nihon Buyō      Nihon buyō is different from most other traditional dances.
It is intended for entertainment on stage.
The second part of nihon buyō is Noh.
Thus  the present day form of nihon buyō was influenced by dance forms like ballet.
Folk dances      There are a wide variety of folk dances in Japan.
Folk dances are often the basis from which other dance forms developed.
The emblem of the Date clan incorporates two tree sparrows.
Bon Odori      Bon odori is a type of folk dance performed during the Obon Festival.
It was originally a dance to welcome the spirits of the dead.
These dances and the music that accompanies them are different for every region of Japan.
Usually  the bon dance involves people dancing around a yagura  a high wooden scaffold.
The people move either counter clockwise or clockwise  away and towards the yagura.
For the hanagasa odori  the dancers use straw hats with flowers on them.
This form of dance is intended to be performed only by women.
Japanese dolls  人形  ningyō  lit.
human form   are one of the traditional Japanese crafts.
They are good luck charms and symbols of perseverance and resilience.
Sets of dolls came to include larger and more elaborate figures  and more of them.
Types    It was during the Edo period that most of the traditional dolls developed.
Hina dolls are the dolls for Hinamatsuri  the doll festival on March 3.
Armor  helmets  and weapons are made of lacquered paper  often with metal accents.
Gosho dolls show fat  cute babies in a simplified form.
Kimekomi dolls  ja 木目込人形  are made of wood.
The cloth is glued on and the edges tucked in.
These dolls have become a very popular craft and kits with finished heads can be purchased.
They often depict legendary heroes.
Kokeshi dolls have been made for 150 years  and are from Northern Honshū  the main island of Japan.
They were originally made as toys for children of farmers.
They have no arms or legs  but a large head and cylindrical body  representing little girls.
Iki ningyō are life sized lifelike dolls  that were popular in misemono shows.
Daruma are spherical dolls with red bodies and white faces without pupils.
Usually daruma dolls are purchased without eyes.
One eye is filled when making a wish  the other when the wish is fulfilled.
Wishes can be made throughout the year  but it is common in Japan to do it on New Year s Day.
Teru teru bozu   shine shine monk   is strictly speaking not a doll.
Bisque dolls are made of fired clay.
Anesama ningyo tend to be three dimensional  whereas shiori ningyō are flat.
Anesama ningyo often have elaborate hairstyles and costumes made of high quality washi paper.
They often lack facial features.
Those from Shimane prefecture are especially famous.
BJDs can be very realistic looking or based more on the anime aesthetic.
They are made of polyurethane resin which makes them very durable.
Collectors     Japanese dolls  are broken down into several subcategories.
In the nineteenth century ningyo were introduced to the West.
Doll collecting has since become a popular pastime in the West.

Adeline produced many works throughout his career as a working artist.
Unlike Tissot  Adeline is recognized as a true collector.

Almost all written Japanese sentences contain a mixture of kanji and kana.
Japanese primary and secondary school students are required to learn 2 136 jōyō kanji as of 2010.
Certain names may be written in hiragana or katakana  or some combination of these and kanji.
Unusual or nonstandard kanji readings may be glossed using furigana.
Kanji compounds are sometimes given arbitrary readings for stylistic purposes.
The word 接続  meaning  connection   is normally pronounced setsuzoku.
furigana  振り仮名 —phonetic renderings of kanji placed above or beside the kanji character.
For example  the root of the verb 見る  miru   see   is normally written with the kanji 見.
Although rare  there are some words that use all three scripts in the same word.
Modern Japanese also uses another writing format  called yokogaki  横書き .
This writing format is horizontal and reads from left to right  as in English.
The exclamation mark  ！   is restricted to informal writing.
Colons and semicolons are available but are not common in ordinary text.
Quotation marks are written as 「 ... 」  and nested quotation marks as 『 ... 』.
Several bracket styles and dashes are available.
At the same time  native Japanese already had words corresponding to many borrowed kanji.
Authors increasingly used kanji to represent these words.
This Japanese derived reading is known as kun yomi  訓読み .
A kanji may have none  one  or several on yomi and kun yomi.
The same character may be read several different ways depending on the word.
the station sign at Tokyo reads 駅京東 .
The post war reforms have mostly survived  although some of the restrictions have been relaxed.
The jōyō kanji list was extended to 2 136 characters in 2010.

Other systems of romanization include Nihon shiki  JSL  and Wāpuro rōmaji.

Pronunciation and etymology    Yen derives from the Japanese word 圓  えん  en   eɴ   lit.
The coins and the name also appeared in Japan.

The yen was officially adopted by the Meiji government in an Act signed on June 27  1871.
The new currency was gradually introduced beginning from July of that year.
The yen replaced Tokugawa coinage  a complex monetary system of the Edo period based on the mon.
In that year  Japan adopted a gold exchange standard and hence froze the value of the yen at  0.50.
Undervalued yen     By 1971  the yen had become undervalued.
This agreement set the exchange rate at ¥308 per US 1.
The re emergence of trade surpluses drove the yen back up to ¥211 in 1978.
From ¥221 per US 1 in 1981  the average value of the yen actually dropped to ¥239 per US 1 in 1985.
Effect of the Plaza Accord      In 1985  a dramatic change began.
After declining somewhat in 1989 and 1990  it reached a new high of ¥123 to US 1 in December 1992.
Other major currencies  except the Swiss franc  have been declining relative to the yen.
The Bank of Japan hopes to bring Japan from deflation to inflation  aiming for 2  inflation.
The amount of purchases is so large that it is expected to double the money supply.
Coins     Coins were introduced in 1870.
There were silver 5   10   20  and 50 sen and 1 yen  and gold 2   5   10  and 20 yen.
Gold 1 yen were introduced in 1871  followed by copper 1 rin  ​1⁄2   1  and 2 sen in 1873.
Cupronickel 5 sen coins were introduced in 1889.
In 1920  cupro nickel 10 sen coins were introduced.
Clay 5  and 10 sen coins were produced in 1945  but not issued for circulation.
After the war  brass 50 sen  1  and 5 yen were introduced between 1946 and 1948.
In 1955  the current type of aluminium 1 yen was introduced  along with unholed  nickel 50 yen.
In 1957  silver 100 yen pieces were introduced  followed by the holed 50 yen coin in 1959.
These were replaced in 1967 by the current cupro nickel type  along with a smaller 50 yen coin.
Only one coin per customer is available from banks in each prefecture.

Jordan is bordered by Saudi Arabia  Iraq  Syria  Israel and Palestine  West Bank .
Jordan is strategically located at the crossroads of Asia  Africa and Europe.
Three stable kingdoms emerged there at the end of the Bronze Age  Ammon  Moab and Edom.
Later rulers include the Nabataean Kingdom  the Roman Empire  and the Ottoman Empire.
Jordan is a founding member of the Arab League and the Organisation of Islamic Co operation.
Jordan has been repeatedly referred to as an  oasis of stability  in a turbulent region.
The kingdom is also a refuge to thousands of Iraqi Christians fleeing persecution by ISIL.
The Old Testament refers to the area as  the other side of the Jordan .
Early Arab chronicles referred to the river as Al Urdunn  corresponding to the Semitic Yarden.
Jund Al Urdunn was a military district around the river in the early Islamic era.
Trade and movement of people in the Middle East peaked  spreading and refining civilizations.
Ancient Egyptians expanded towards the Levant and controlled both banks of the Jordan River.
The stele constitutes one of the most important direct accounts of Biblical history.
Babylonians took over the empire after its disintegration in 627 BC.
The kingdoms were reduced to vassals  which they remained under the Persian and Hellenic Empires.
The Edict of Thessalonka made Christianity the official state religion in 380 AD.
Transjordan prospered during the Byzantine era  and Christian churches were built everywhere.
Umm ar Rasas in southern Amman contains at least 16 Byzantine churches.
Transjordan was an essential territory for the conquest of Damascus.
The first  or Rashidun  caliphate was followed by that of the Ummayads  661–750 .
The Abbasid Caliphate s campaign to take over the Umayyad s began in Transjordan.
During Abbasid rule  750–969   several Arab tribes moved northwards and settled in the Levant.
Transjordan was of marginal importance to the Ottoman authorities.
As a result  Ottoman presence was virtually absent and reduced to annual tax collection visits.
In 1833 Ibrahim Pasha turned on the Ottomans and established his rule over the Levant.
His oppressive policies led to the unsuccessful peasants  revolt in Palestine in 1834.
Egyptian rule was forcibly ended in 1841  with Ottoman rule restored.
Muslim Circassians and Chechens  fleeing Russian persecution  sought refuge in the Levant.

Hussein ascended to the throne in 1953 at the age of 17.
Jordan witnessed great political uncertainty in the following period.
The 1950s were a period of political upheaval  as Nasserism and Pan Arabism swept the Arab World.
The Arab states were defeated and Jordan lost control of the West Bank to Israel.
The fedayeen activities soon became a threat to Jordan s rule of law.

Climate      The climate in Jordan varies greatly.
The country s average elevation is 812 m  2 664 ft   SL .
Winter also sees frequent showers and occasional snowfall in some western elevated areas.
Ecology      Over 2 000 plant species have been recorded in Jordan.
Politics and government     Jordan is a unitary state under a constitutional monarchy.
The king retains wide executive and legislative powers from the government and parliament.
The judiciary is independent according to the constitution.
The king is the head of state and commander in chief of the army.
Although Islam is the state religion  the constitution preserves religious and personal freedoms.

Yom Kippur    Day of Atonement   is the holiest day of the Jewish year.
It is a day of communal fasting and praying for forgiveness for one s sins.
Many non religious Jews make a point of attending synagogue services and fasting on Yom Kippur.
On the eve of Yom Kippur  before candles are lit  a prefast meal  the  seuda mafseket   is eaten.

The following day  prayers are held from morning to evening.

Synagogues and religious buildings      Synagogues are Jewish houses of prayer and study.

Dietary laws  kashrut      The Jewish dietary laws are known as kashrut.
For example  in order to be considered kosher  mammals must have split hooves and chew their cud.
The pig is arguably the most well known example of a non kosher animal.
Although it has split hooves  it does not chew its cud.
For seafood to be kosher  the animal must have fins and scales.
Concerning birds  a list of non kosher species is given in the Torah.
However  traditions exist about the kashrut status of a few birds.
For example  both chickens and turkeys are permitted in most communities.
Without the proper slaughtering practices even an otherwise kosher animal will be rendered treif.
The slaughtering process is intended to be quick and relatively painless to the animal.
These laws are also known as niddah  literally  separation   or family purity.
The baby boy is also given his Hebrew name in the ceremony.
In the Reform movement  both girls and boys have their bat bar mitzvah at age thirteen.

Courts    Japan s court system is divided into four basic tiers.
Summary court judges are not career judges.
Qualification as a regular judge is not required.
They are only able to imprison defendants in a few special cases.
Summary courts are presided over by one judge.
There are 50 district courts with additional 203 branches.
These are the courts of general jurisdiction and the principal court of first instance.
They also handle bankruptcy hearings.
Attorneys sit on either side of the courtroom  facing the center.
In a criminal case  the accused faces the judges from the rear of the courtroom.
The witness box is in the center  also facing the judges.
There are eight high courts  高等裁判所 Kōtō saibansho .
A high court usually sits in the same manner as a three judge district court.
Each court is led by a President  who is appointed by the Cabinet.
An appeal to a high court is called kōso  控訴 .
The Chief Justice is nominated by the Cabinet and appointed to office by the Emperor.
Typically  there are six lay judges and three professional judges for one case.
The decision has to be by majority and include at least one of the professional judges.

Dating     Odai Yamamoto I site in Aomori Prefecture currently has the oldest pottery in Japan.
This appears to be plain  undecorated pottery.
Such a date puts the development of pottery before the warming at the end of the Pleistocene.
Linear relief  pottery was also found at Fukui Cave Layer III dating to 13 850–12 250 BC.
This site is located in Nagasaki Prefecture  Kyushu.
Some sources claim archaeological discoveries as far back as the 14th millennium BCE.
Chronology     The Jōmon Period in Ancient Japan lasted until roughly 300 BCE.

Kabuki  歌舞伎  is a classical Japanese dance drama.
This form of theatre was perfected in the late 17th and mid 18th century.
Kabuki is therefore sometimes translated as  the art of singing and dancing .
These are  however  ateji characters which do not reflect actual etymology.
The kanji of skill generally refers to a performer in kabuki theatre.
The expression kabukimono  歌舞伎者  referred originally to those who were bizarrely dressed.
It originated in the 17th century.
Female performers played both men and women in comic playlets about ordinary life.
The style was immediately popular  and Okuni was asked to perform before the Imperial Court.
For this reason  kabuki was also known as  遊女歌舞妓   lit.   prostitute kabuki   during this period.
The area surrounding kabuki theatres also featured a number of shops selling kabuki souvenirs.
Despite its popularity  the ruling shogunate held unfavorable views of kabuki performances.

Kaidō  街道   road   were roads in Japan dating from the Edo period.
They act important roles in transportation like the Appian way of ancient Roman roads.
Major examples include the Edo Five Routes  all of which started at Edo  modern day Tokyo .
Minor examples include sub routes such as the Hokuriku Kaidō and the Nagasaki Kaidō.
These names were used for administrative units  and the roads within these units.
Many highways and railway lines in modern Japan follow the ancient routes and carry the same names.

Kansas    listen   is a state in the center of the United States.
Its capital is Topeka and its largest city is Wichita.
For thousands of years  what is now Kansas was home to numerous and diverse Native American tribes.
Tribes in the eastern part of the state generally lived in villages along the river valleys.
Tribes in the western part of the state were semi nomadic and hunted large herds of bison.
Kansas was first settled by Americans in 1827 with the establishment of Fort Leavenworth.
Residents of Kansas are called Kansans.
Mount Sunflower is Kansas s highest point at 4 039 feet  1 231 meters .
Between 1763 and 1803 the territory of Kansas was integrated into Spanish Louisiana.
From 1812 to 1821  Kansas was part of the Missouri Territory.
Wagon ruts from the trail are still visible in the prairie today.
Missouri and Arkansas sent settlers into Kansas all along its eastern border.
These settlers attempted to sway votes in favor of slavery.
At the same time  the Chisholm Trail was opened and the Wild West era commenced in Kansas.
Wild Bill Hickok was a deputy marshal at Fort Riley and a marshal at Hays and Abilene.
Kansas is located equidistant from the Pacific and Atlantic oceans.
The geographic center of the 48 contiguous states is in Smith County near Lebanon.
The geographic center of Kansas is in Barton County.
Spring River is located between Riverton and Baxter Springs.
Most of the precipitation falls during both the summer and the spring.
Summers are hot  often very hot  and generally less humid.
Winters are highly changeable between warm and very cold.
Frost free days range from more than 200 days in the south  to 130 days in the northwest.
Thus  Kansas is the country s ninth or tenth sunniest state  depending on the source.
Western Kansas is as sunny as parts of California and Arizona.
Kansas is prone to severe weather  especially in the spring and the early summer.
Kansas averages more than 50 tornadoes annually.
Severe thunderstorms sometimes drop some very large hail over Kansas as well.
Furthermore  these storms can even bring in flash flooding and damaging straight line winds.
Alton and Lebanon are approximately 50 miles  80 km  apart.
As of 2004  the population included 149 800 foreign born  5.5  of the state population .
Mexicans are present in the southwest and make up nearly half the population in certain counties.
They have sometimes successfully raised lawsuits against the city of Topeka.
Kansas has 627 incorporated cities.
Historic Leavenworth  founded in 1854  was the first incorporated city in Kansas.
North of the city  Fort Leavenworth is the oldest active Army post west of the Mississippi River.
To the west  nearly a quarter million people reside in the Topeka metropolitan area.
Topeka is the state capital and home to Washburn University and Washburn Institute of Technology.
Wichita is the largest city in the state in terms of both land area and population.
Before Wichita was  The Air Capital  it was a Cowtown.
The population of Goddard has grown by more than 11  per year since 2000.
Other fast growing cities include Andover  Maize  Park City  Derby  and Haysville.
To the southwest of Wichita is Freeport  the state s smallest incorporated city  population 5 .
It was also the home of newspaper man William Allen White.
Big Brutus  is located 1.5 miles  2.4 km  outside the city of West Mineral.
South of Salina is the small city of Lindsborg with its numerous Dala horses.
Much of the architecture and decor of this town has a distinctly Swedish style.
To the west is Lucas  the Grassroots Art Capital of Kansas.
The city of Liberal is located along the southern Santa Fe Trail route.
The first wind farm in the state was built east of Montezuma.
Garden City has the Lee Richardson Zoo.
As of 2018  there were 59 600 farms in Kansas  86  0.14   of which are certified organic farms.
Approximately 40  of all winter wheat grown in the US is grown in Kansas.
Roughly 95  of the wheat grown in the state is hard red winter wheat.
Kansas is ranked eighth in US petroleum production.
Kansas is also ranked eighth in US natural gas production.
Average monthly production was over 32 billion cubic feet  0.91 cubic kilometers .
The state s economy is also heavily influenced by the aerospace industry.

Many of those airfields live on today as municipal airports.

Debana wazaThis technique involves striking the opponent as they are about to strike.
This can also be achieved by inducing the opponent to attack  then employing one of the Oji waza.
Here  timing has to be correct.

This technique needs to be smooth.
Uchiotoshi wazaThis waza knocks an opponent s shinai to the right or left.

Kaeshi wazaThis technique is a response.
As the opponent strikes  the opponent parries their shinai with the initiator s.

In competition  there are usually three referees  審判  shinpan .
Each referee holds a red flag and a white flag in opposing hands.
Usually  at least two referees must agree for a point to be awarded.
Play is stopped after each point is awarded.
Kendo competitions are usually a three point match.
The first competitor to score two points  therefore  wins the match.
If the time limit is reached and only one competitor has a point  that competitor wins.
In the case of a tie  there are several options   Hiki wake  引き分け   The match is declared a draw.
Enchō  延長   The match is continued until either competitor scores a point.
Hantei  判定   The victor is decided by the referees.
The three referees vote for victor by each raising one of their respective flags simultaneously.
The World Kendo Championships have been held every three years since 1970.
Kendo is also one of the martial arts in the World Combat Games.
The dan levels are from first dan  初段  sho dan  to tenth dan  十段  jū dan .
There are usually six grades below first dan  known as kyu.
The exam for 1st kyu  ikkyū  is often their first exam and grade.
Adults generally will do their 1st dan  shodan  as their first exam.
A larger  more qualified panel is usually assembled to assess the higher dan grades.
The eighth dan kendo exam is extremely difficult  with a reported pass rate of less than 1 percent.
These are renshi  錬士   kyōshi  教士   and hanshi  範士 .
The title is affixed to the front of the dan grade when said  for example renshi roku dan  錬士六段 .
The qualifications for each title are below.

Terms     The fabrics that kimono are made from are classified in two categories within Japan.
These techniques range from intricate shibori tie dye to rice paste resist dyeing.
Kimono linings are made from bolts of the same width.
Historically  kimono were taken apart entirely to be washed   a process known as arai hari.
Terms     A number of different terms are used to refer to the different parts of a kimono.
These terms refer to parts of a kimono   Dōura  胴裏   the upper lining of a kimono.
Hakkake  八掛   the lower lining of a kimono.
Furi  振り   lit.   dangling  — the part of the sleeve left hanging below the armhole.
Maemigoro  前身頃   lit.   front body  — the front panels on a kimono  excluding the okumi.
The panels are divided into the  right maemigoro  and  left maemigoro .
Miyatsukuchi  身八つ口   the opening under the sleeve on a woman s kimono.
Okumi  衽   the overlapping front panel.
Sodeguchi  袖口   the wrist opening of the sleeve.
Sodetsuke  袖付   the kimono armhole.
Tamoto  袂   the sleeve pouch of a kimono.
Tomoeri  共衿   lit.   over collar  — the collar cover sewn on top of the uraeri.
Ushiromigoro  後身頃   lit.   back body  — the back panels.
The back panels consist of the  right ushiromigoro  and  left ushiromigoro .

Uchikake       Uchikake  打ち掛け  are highly formal kimono worn only in bridalwear or on stage.

The garment originated in the Kamakura Period  1185 1333 CE   and are worn without hakama.
The wata bōshi is always white and worn with shiromuku.
Both geisha and maiko wear variations on common accessories that are not found in everyday dress.
For certain traditional holidays and occasions some specific types of kimono accessories are worn.
Okobo are also worn by young women on seijin no hi  Coming of Age Day .
Datejime can be made of a variety of fabrics  including silk  linen and elastic.
Hachimaki  鉢巻  Traditional Japanese stylized headband  worn to keep sweat off of one s face.
Hadagi are made of either linen  silk crepe  or cotton cloth.
The sleeves on this type of shirt are rather narrow  and are at times omitted altogether.
A hakama is typically pleated at the waist and fastened by waist ties over the obi.

half wrap   The worker s version of the more formal haori.

Haori himo  羽織紐  A tasseled  woven string fastener for haori.
The most formal colour is white  see also fusa above .
belly wrap   Are items of Japanese clothing that cover the stomach.
They are worn for health  fashion and superstitious reasons.
It is worn with a slip like wrap tied around the waist  with the nagajuban worn on top.
