The Qiang people  Chinese  羌族  pinyin  Qiāngzú  Qiangic  Rrmea  are an ethnic group in China.
When Qiang was officially designated an ethnic group in 1950  they numbered only 35 600.
Another 49 200 people reclaimed their Qiang ethnicity from 1982 1989.
In total  some 200 000 Han people became Qiang.
The Qiangs also use Chinese characters.
The Qiang find marriage important.
In the past  marriages were arranged by an individual s parents  with approval from the individual.
The Qiang also have strict customs regarding birth and death.
After she has given birth  the woman is not allowed into the kitchen for one month thereafter.
It would be considered a sinful action against the kitchen and family gods.
Stillborn or premature babies are not considered human beings by the Qiang.
Culture and lifestyle     The Qiang today are mountain dwellers.
The inhabitants of fortress village or village cluster have close contact in social life.
Owing to its ethnic diversity  Qiang culture has influenced and been influenced by other cultures.
Following age old traditions  their hair and legs are bound.
Consumption of wine and smoking of orchid leaves are also popular among the Qiangs.
If the third floor does not exist  the grains will be kept on the first or second floor instead.

Others who are excellent masons are good at digging wells.
Embroidery and drawn work are done extemporaneously without any designs.
Others  who live near the Tibetans  follow Tibetan Buddhism.
There are as well very small minorities of Muslims.
In certain places  Shanwang  the mountain god  is considered to represent the supreme god.
The Qiang people have also adopted many practices of the Taoists.
On top of the pagoda  a white stone is placed together with ox and sheep horns.

Shape and position within characters    Radicals may appear in any position in a character.
These are loose rules  though  and exceptions are plenty.
They may be narrowed  shortened  or may have different shapes entirely.
Changes in shape  rather than simple distortion  may result in fewer pen strokes.
In some cases  combinations may have alternates.
The shape of the component can depend on its placement with other elements in the character.

Rakugo  落語  literally  fallen words   is a form of Japanese verbal entertainment of yose.
The lone storyteller  落語家  rakugoka  sits on a raised platform  a kōza  高座 .
The story always involves the dialogue of two or more characters.
Lexical background    Rakugo was originally known as karukuchi  軽口 .
The monologue always ends with a narrative stunt  punch line  known as ochi  落ち  lit.
In many of these forms the ochi  which is essential to the original rakugo  is absent.
Many groups of performers were formed  and collections of texts were finally printed.
These were enacted in small public venues  or in the streets  and printed and sold as pamphlets.
Important contributors     Many artists contributed to the development of rakugo.
Some were simply performers  but many also composed original works.
Tatekawa Enba I  1743–1822  was author of the Rakugo rokugi  The Six Meanings of Rakugo .
An example from Yonezawa Hikohachi s collection   A man faints in a bathing tub.
Once the water has flowed completely out of the tub he says   Fine.
Now put a lid on it and carry the guy to the cemetery.
For the poor man is already dead.
Some examples include Akashiya Sanma  Shōfukutei Tsurube II  and Shōfukutei Shōhei.

History          Origin     Ramen is a Japanese adaptation of Chinese wheat noodles.

Robotics is an interdisciplinary field that integrates computer science and engineering.

The goal of robotics is to design machines that can help and assist humans.
Robotics develops machines that can substitute for humans and replicate human actions.
Robots can take on any form but some are made to resemble humans in appearance.
Such robots attempt to replicate walking  lifting  speech  cognition  or any other human activity.

Other      Other common forms of sensing in robotics use lidar  radar  and sonar.

Mechanical grippers      One of the most common types of end effectors are  grippers .
Fingers can  for example  be made of a chain with a metal wire run through it.
Hands that resemble and work more like a human hand include the Shadow Hand and the Robonaut hand.
Hands that are of a mid level complexity include the Delft hand.
Mechanical grippers can come in various types  including friction and encompassing jaws.
Friction jaws use all the force of the gripper to hold the object in place using friction.
Encompassing jaws cradle the object in place  using less friction.

Walking applied to robots      Walking is a difficult and dynamic problem to solve.

Control     The mechanical structure of a robot must be controlled to perform tasks.
Sensors give information about the environment or the robot itself  e.g.
The processing phase can range in complexity.
At a reactive level  it may translate raw sensor information directly into actuator commands.
Sensor fusion may first be used to estimate parameters of interest  e.g.
Techniques from control theory convert the task into commands that drive the actuators.
Cognitive models try to represent the robot  the world  and how they interact.
Pattern recognition and computer vision can be used to track objects.
Mapping techniques can be used to build maps of the world.
Autonomy levels      Control systems may also have varying levels of autonomy.
An autonomous robot may go without human interaction for extended periods of time .
Higher levels of autonomy do not necessarily require more complex cognitive capabilities.
A human controls each movement  each machine actuator change is specified by the operator.
The operator specifies only the task and the robot manages itself to complete it.
The machine will create and complete all its tasks without human interaction.

This happens without any direct programming of the robots by the researchers.
Researchers use this method both to create better robots  and to explore the nature of evolution.

The romanization of Japanese is the use of Latin script to write the Japanese language.

History    The earliest Japanese romanization system was based on Portuguese orthography.

Rugby union is a popular sport around the world  played by male and female players of all ages.
The Rugby World Cup  first held in 1987  is held every four years.
The first World Cup Sevens tournament was held at Murrayfield in 1993.
As a result of the expansion to four teams  the tournament was renamed The Rugby Championship.
Players in a team are divided into eight forwards  two more than in rugby league  and seven backs.
Forwards play a vital role in tackling and rucking opposing players.
The third position in the front row is the hooker.
Hookers normally throw the ball in at line outs.
Second row      The second row consists of two locks or lock forwards.
Locks are usually the tallest players in the team  and specialise as line out jumpers.
The three positions in the back row are the two flankers and the number 8.
They are usually the most mobile forwards in the game.
Their main role is to win possession through  turn overs .
Backs     The role of the backs is to create and convert point scoring opportunities.
They are generally smaller  faster and more agile than the forwards.
Half backs      The half backs consist of two positions  the scrum half and the fly half.
The fly half is crucial to a team s game plan  orchestrating the team s performance.
Many fly halves are also their team s goal kickers.
The scrum half is the link between the forwards and the backs.
They also feed the scrum and sometimes have to act as a fourth loose forward.
The wings are generally positioned on the outside of the backline.
Their primary function is to finish off moves and score tries.
Full back      The full back is normally positioned several metres behind the back line.
The values of each of these scoring methods have been changed over the years.
In actual gameplay the length of a pitch can vary.
Anywhere between 6 and 22 metres  7 and 24 yd  behind each try line serves as the in goal area.
The minimum height for posts is 3.4 metres  3.7 yd .
The dropkick must make contact with the ground before kicked.
The sides exchange ends of the field after the half time break.
Only the player with the ball may be tackled or rucked.
If the player kicks directly into touch  i.e.
Such a circumstance is called a breakdown and each is governed by a specific law.
The two props are typically amongst the strongest players on the team.

Behind the second row is the number 8.

Saga Prefecture  佐賀県  Saga ken  is a prefecture of Japan located on the island of Kyūshū.
After the Boshin War  many people from Saga Domain assisted in the Meiji Restoration.
After the Japanese invasions of Korea the castle fell in 1598.
1607  Control of Saga Domain moved from the Ryūzōji clan to the Nabeshima clan.

1889  April 1  The city of Saga is founded.

1935  The Japanese National Railways Saga Line opens.
1954  During the Great Showa Merger the cities of Tosu  Imari  Takeo  Kashima and Taku are formed.
At this point there are 7 cities  8 districts  18 towns and 35 villages in Saga Prefecture.
1972  With the closing of the Nishiki coal mine  all coal mines in Saga are closed.
1975  The Genkai Nuclear Power Plant begins operation.
1987  The Japanese National Railways Saga Line closes.
1992  The Yoshinogari History Park opens to the public.
1998  The Saga Airport opens in Kawasoe  in what is now the city of Saga.
2005  As a part of the Great Heisei Merger various municipalities are reorganized.
2006  The Great Heisei Merger continues.
2011  March 12  The Kyushu Shinkansen opens.
There are six prefectural parks and one quasi national park in Saga.

Like other rice wines  when sake is brewed  these conversions occur simultaneously.
History     The origin of sake is unclear.
In the Heian period  sake was used for religious ceremonies  court festivals  and drinking games.
The brewing of shōchū  called  Imo–sake  started  and was sold at the central market in Kyoto.
Around 30 000 breweries sprang up around the country within a year.
Landowners who grew rice crops would have surplus rice at the end of the season.
Rather than letting these leftovers go to waste  they shipped it to their breweries.
At the time  sake comprised 30  of Japan s tax revenue.
75  of today s sake is made using this technique.
There were a few breweries producing  sake  that contained no rice at all.
Sake consumption continued to decrease while the quality of sake steadily improved.
More breweries are also turning to older methods of production.
The number of sake breweries is also declining.
While there were 3 229 breweries nationwide in fiscal 1975  the number had fallen to 1 845 in 2007.
It is estimated to be utilized until the Onin War  1467–1477 .
Sake was brewed at Tenryū ji during the Muromachi Period  1336–1573 .
There are at least 80 types of sake rice in Japan.
Among these  Yamadanishiki  Gohyakumangoku  Miyamanishiki and Omachi rice are popular.
Sake rice is used only for making sake  because some say it is unpalatable for eating.
Premium sake is mostly made from sake rice however non premium sake is mostly made from table rice.
The reason for polishing is a result of the composition and structure of the rice grain itself.
That desirable pocket of starch in the center of the grain is called the shinpaku  心白  しんぱく .
It usually takes two to three days to polish rice down to less than half its original size.
The mineral content of the water can be important in the final product.
Manganese  when exposed to ultraviolet light  will also contribute to discoloration.
The first region known for having great water was the Nada Gogō in Hyōgo Prefecture.
Breweries may use tap water and filter and adjust components.
Kōji kin     Kōji kin  Aspergillus oryzae  spores are another important component of sake.
Kōji kin is an enzyme secreting fungus.
It is also used to make alcoholic beverages  notably sake.
This process of starch conversion into simpler sugars  e.g.
glucose or maltose  is called saccharification.
Yeast then turns this glucose into alcohol via fermentation.
To date  there have been several reported cases of animals  e.g.
Fermentation      Sake fermentation is a 3 step process called sandan shikomi.
This mixture becomes known as the moromi  the main mash during sake fermentation .
On the fourth day of the fermentation  the third step of the process  called tomezoe  takes place.
Maturation     Like other brewed beverages  sake tends to benefit from a period of storage.
Nine to twelve months are required for sake to mature.
Tōji     Tōji  杜氏  is the job title of the sake brewer  named after Du Kang.
The title of tōji was historically passed from father to son.
Today new tōji are either veteran brewery workers or are trained at universities.
Futsū shu is the equivalent of table wine and accounts for the majority of sake produced.
This method was the standard for 300 years  but it is rare today.
Yamahai  山廃  is a simplified version of the kimoto method  introduced in the early 1900s.
Yamahai skips the step of making a paste out of the starter mash.
Sokujō  速醸    quick fermentation   is the modern method of preparing the starter mash.
Sokujō sake tends to have a lighter flavor than kimoto or yamahai.
Different handling after fermentation      Namazake  生酒  is sake that has not been pasteurized.
It requires refrigerated storage and has a shorter shelf life than pasteurized sake.
Nigorizake  濁り酒  is cloudy sake.
The sake is passed through a loose mesh to separate it from the mash.
It is not filtered thereafter and there is much rice sediment in the bottle.
Before serving  the bottle is shaken to mix the sediment and turn the sake white or cloudy.
Taruzake  樽酒  is sake aged in wooden barrels or bottled in wooden casks.
The wood used is Cryptomeria  杉  sugi   which is also known as Japanese cedar.
Sake casks are often tapped ceremonially for the opening of buildings  businesses  parties  etc.
Because the wood imparts a strong flavor  premium sake is rarely used for this type.
The result is usually a more acidic   greener  sake.
Sake produced this way is sometimes called shizukuzake  雫酒   meaning  drip sake .
Doburoku  濁酒  is the classic home brew style of sake  although home brewing is illegal in Japan .
It is created by simply adding kōji mold to steamed rice and water and letting the mixture ferment.
The resulting sake is somewhat like a chunkier version of nigorizake.
Jizake  地酒  is locally brewed sake  the equivalent of microbrewing beer.
Kuroshu  黒酒  is sake made from unpolished rice  i.e.  brown rice   and is more like huangjiu.
Teiseihaku shu  低精白酒  is sake with a deliberately high rice polishing ratio.
When the SMV was first used  0 was designated the point between sweet sake and dry sake.
Kasu  粕  are pressed sake lees  the solids left after pressing and filtering.
Taste and flavor    The label on a bottle of sake gives a rough indication of its taste.
Aminosan do  アミノ酸度  indicates a taste of umami or savoriness.
As the proportion of amino acids rises  the sake tastes more savory.
Sake can have many flavor notes  such as fruits  flowers  herbs  and spices.
Hot sake that has cooled  kanzamashi 燗冷まし  may be reheated.
Seasonality     Traditionally sake was brewed only in the winter.
The leaves start green  but turn brown over time  reflecting the maturation of the sake.
These are now hung outside many restaurants serving sake.
When premium sake is opened it begins to oxidize  which affects the taste.
If the sake is kept in the refrigerator more than three days  it will lose its  best  flavor.
This does not mean it should be disposed of if not consumed.
Generally  sake can keep very well and taste good after weeks in the refrigerator.
Ceremonial use    Sake is often consumed as part of Shinto purification rituals.
Sake served to gods as offerings prior to drinking are called o miki  御神酒  or miki  神酒 .
This sake  called iwai zake   celebration sake    is served freely to all to spread good fortune.
At the New Year many Japanese people drink a special sake called toso.
In some regions  the first sips of toso are taken in order of age  from the youngest to the eldest.
Events    October 1 is the official  Sake Day   日本酒の日   Nihonshu no Hi   of Japan.
It is also called  World Sake Day .

The best hypotheses lead to predictions that can be tested in various ways.
A hypothesis is a conjecture  based on knowledge obtained while seeking answers to the question.
The hypothesis might be very specific  or it might be broad.
Scientists then test hypotheses by conducting experiments or studies.
Experiments can take place anywhere from a garage to CERN s Large Hadron Collider.
There are difficulties in a formulaic statement of method  however.
Overview     The scientific method is the process by which science is carried out.
The scientific method is of necessity also an expression of an opposition to claims that e.g.
There are difficulties in a formulaic statement of method  however.
but can also be open ended  as in  How can I design a drug to cure this particular disease?
If the answer is already known  a different question that builds on the evidence can be posed.
A statistical hypothesis is a conjecture about a given statistical population.
For example  the population might be people with a particular disease.
The conjecture might be that a new drug will cure the disease in some of those people.
Researchers normally want to show that the null hypothesis is false.
The alternative hypothesis is the desired outcome  that the drug does better than chance.
Prediction      This step involves determining the logical consequences of the hypothesis.
One or more predictions are then selected for further testing.
Scientists  and other people  test hypotheses by conducting experiments.
If they agree  confidence in the hypothesis increases  otherwise  it decreases.
Agreement does not assure that the hypothesis is true  future experiments may reveal problems.
For example  tests of medical treatments are commonly run as double blind tests.
Such hints can bias the responses of the test subjects.
Furthermore  failure of an experiment does not necessarily mean the hypothesis is false.
Astronomers do experiments  searching for planets around distant stars.
As a result  evidence about broader topics is usually accumulated gradually.

The Japanese archipelago separates the sea from the Pacific Ocean.
The sea has no large islands  bays or capes.
Few rivers discharge into the sea and their total contribution to the water exchange is within 1 .
Therefore  fishing is the dominant economic activity in the region.
It had long been navigated by Asian and  from the 18th century  by European ships.
They also documented the cyclonal character of the sea currents.
The aquatic life was described by V. K. Brazhnikov in 1899–1902 and P. Yu.
They primarily targeted right whales  but began catching humpbacks as right whale catches declined.
Right whales were caught from March to September  with peak catches in May and June.
The onset of formation of the Japan Arc was in the Early Miocene.
The south part of the Japanese archipelago remained as a relatively large landmass.
The land area had expanded northward in the Late Miocene.
The straits were formed in recent geologic periods.
The oldest of them are the Tsugaru and Tsushima straits.
All the straits are rather shallow with a minimal depth of the order of 100 meters or less.
The bottom of this part is relatively flat  but has a few plateaus.
Yamato Ridge is of continental origin and is composed of granite  rhyolite  andesite and basalt.
It has an uneven bottom covered with boulders of volcanic rock.
Most other areas of the sea are of oceanic origin.
Pelagic sediments of red mud dominate the deeper regions.There are no large islands in the sea.
Most of the smaller ones are near the eastern coast  except for Ulleungdo  South Korea .
The deepest  and thus the last to close  is the western channel of the Korea Strait.
Climate     The sea climate is characterized by warm waters and monsoons.
The evaporation is blown further south causing snowfall in the mountainous western coasts of Japan.
Tsunami waves were also recorded in the sea.
In addition  the monsoon enhances the surface water convection  down to the depths of 30 m  98 ft .
Ice cover is continuous only in the bays and forms floating patches in the open sea.
Hydrology     The sea currents circulate in the counterclockwise direction.
They also feed the Sōya Current and exit through the La Perouse Strait to the Sea of Okhotsk.
Winter temperatures are 0 °C  32 °F  or below in the north and 10–14 °C  50–57 °F  in the south.
In winter  the temperature is almost constant with the depth in the northern part of the sea.
Heating by the sun and tropical monsoons increases the depth gradient in spring–summer.
In the north the surface layer  down to 15 m or 49 ft  may heat up to 18–20 °C  64–68 °F .
A typical variation of salinity across the sea in summer is 31.5‰ to 34.5‰ from north to south.
The depth distribution of salinity is relatively constant.
The surface layer tends to be more fresh in the sea parts which experience ice melting and rains.
The average water density is 1.0270 g cm3 in the north and 1.0255 g cm3 in the south in winter.
It lowers in summer to 1.0253 and 1.0215 g cm3  respectively.
Rainfall  evaporation and riverine inflow make only 1  of the water balance.
Mixed tides occur in Peter the Great Gulf and Korea strait.
The tidal waves have a speed of 10–25 cm s  3.9–9.8 in s  in the open sea.
The amplitude of the tides is relatively low and strongly varies across the sea.
Similar low tides are observed in Hokkaidō  Honshū and south Sakhalin.
The coastal areas contain several kg m2 of biomass.
The demersal  sea bottom  fishes include cod  pollock and Atka mackerel.
Flora and fauna unique to the region near the Sea of Japan are known as  Japan Sea elements .
Economy     Fishery had long been the main economic activity on the Sea of Japan.
These species are however depleted from after World War II.
Squid is mostly caught near the sea center and salmon near the northern and south western shores.
The northeast corner is the Shelikhov Gulf.
The sea is named after Okhotsk  the first Russian settlement in the Far East.
In winter  navigation on the Sea of Okhotsk is impeded by ice floes.
As the ice forms it expels salt into the deeper layers.
Warming inhibits the formation of sea ice and also drives fish populations north.

Japanese usage      In Japan  seals in general are referred to as inkan  印鑑  or hanko  判子 .
Samurai were permitted exclusive use of red ink.
After modernization began in 1870  hanko came into general use throughout Japanese society.
In size  they are comparatively large  measuring 2 to 4 inches  5.1 to 10.2 cm  across.
For personal use  there are at least four kinds of seals.
A registered seal is needed to conduct business and other important or legally binding events.
A jitsuin is used when purchasing a vehicle  marrying  purchasing land  and so on.
The size  shape  material  decoration  and lettering style of jitsuin are closely regulated by law.
It must contain the individual s full family and given name  without abbreviation.
Ancient forms of ideographs are commonplace.
It is sometimes carved by machine.
New  modern intō range in price from less than US 1 to US 100.
The jitsuin is kept in a very secure place such as a bank vault or hidden carefully in one s home.
The paste is usually stored separately.
A ginkō in  銀行印  is used specifically for banking  ginkō means  bank .
The lettering can be red or white  in any font  and with artistic decoration.
They are usually hidden carefully in the owner s home.
Banks always provide stamp pads or ink paste  in addition to dry cleaning tissues.
A mitome in s form is governed by far fewer customs than jitsuin and ginkō in.
The size is the attribute most strongly governed by social custom.
It is usually the size of an American penny or smaller.
They are always geometric figures.
They can have red lettering on a blank field  shubun  or the opposite  hakubun .
Borderlines around their edges are optional.
Inexpensive prefabricated seals are called sanmonban  三文判 .
Prefabricated rubber stamps are unacceptable for business purposes.
They often display only a single hiragana  kanji ideograph  or katakana character carved in it.
They are as often round or oval as they are square.

Gagō in  雅号印  are used by graphic artists to both decorate and sign their work.
The practice goes back several hundred years.
A gago in can be any size  design  or shape.
Their carving is a form of calligraphic art.
Foreign names may be carved in rōmaji  katakana  hiragana  or kanji.
Inkan for standard Japanese names may be purchased prefabricated.
In modern Japan  most people have several inkan.

Korean usage     The seal was first introduced to Korea in approximately 2nd century BC.
The use of seals became popular during the Three Kingdoms of Korea period.
This was used only in communications with China and for the coronation of kings.
Seals were also used by government officials in documents.
These types of seals were called gwanin  관인  官印  and it was supervised by specialist officials.
In modern Korea  the use of seals is still common.
The legal system of registered seals was introduced by the Japanese colonial government in 1914.
The government did pass the  Act on Confirmation  etc.
Thus most Koreans have more than two seals.
These types of seals were called Nakkwan  낙관  落款 .
As seal carving itself was considered a form of art  many artists carved their own seals.
Korean seals are made of wood  jade  or sometimes ivory for more value.
State Seals were generally made of gold or high quality jade.
Rare cases of bronze or steel seals exist.
The seal  now known as the Butuan Ivory Seal  has been declared as a National Cultural Treasure.
The seal is inscribed with the word  Butwan  through a native suyat script.
The ivory seal is now housed at the National Museum of the Philippines.

Junior high school     Lower secondary schools cover grades seven  eight  and nine.
Ages are roughly 12 15 with increased focus on academic studies.
Each class is assigned a homeroom teacher who doubles as counselor.
The subject teachers usually move to a new room for each 50 minute period.
Usually students  lunch is provided by the school itself.
Instruction      Instruction tends to rely on the lecture method.
Teachers also use other media  such as television and radio  and there is some laboratory work.
Students are expected to have mastered daily routines and acceptable behavior.
All course contents are specified in the Course of Study for Lower Secondary Schools.
Moral education and special activities continue to receive attention.
Extracurricular activities     Many students participate in after school clubs.
Soccer  football  clubs are gaining popularity.
Other popular sports clubs include tennis  basketball  gymnastics  Judo and volleyball.
Schools have limited autonomy in developing their curriculum or choosing their textbooks.
There are the large number of mandatory courses  and a few number of electives.

Sentō  銭湯  is a type of Japanese communal bathhouse where customers pay for entrance.
Another type of Japanese public bath is onsen  which uses hot water from a natural hot spring.
Most traditional sentō  however  are very similar to the layout shown on the right.
The curtain is usually blue and shows the kanji 湯  yu  lit.
The men s and the women s side are very similar and differ only slightly.
The other entrance variety is the bandai style.
Above the bandai is usually a large clock.
Immediately in front of the bandai is usually a utility door  to be used by the attendants only.
Often  there is a large shelf storing equipment for regular customers.
There are a number of tables and chairs  including some coin operated massage chairs.
Usually  there is also a scale to measure weight  and sometimes height.
Similarly  in old sentō the height scale may go only to 180 cm.
Local business often advertises in the sentō.
The women s side usually has some baby beds  and may have more mirrors.
The decoration and the advertising is often gender specific on the different sides.
There is usually a refreshment cooler here where customers can self serve and pay the attendant.
Milk drinks are traditional favorites and sometimes there is ice cream.
The bathing area is usually tiled.
Near the entrance area is a supply of small stools and buckets.
The separating wall between the men and the women side is also about 1.5 m high.
The ceiling may be 4 m high  with large windows in the top.
On rare occasions  the separating wall also has a small hole.
On rarer occasions  it may also show a group of warriors or a female nude on the male side.
Playing children or a female beauty often decorate the women s side.
This may use oil or electricity  or any other type of fuel such as wood chippings.
The tall chimneys of the boilers are often used to locate the sentō from far away.

The construction of the shamisen varies in shape  depending on the genre in which it is used.
Construction     The shamisen is a plucked stringed instrument.
The neck of the shamisen is fretless and slimmer than that of a guitar or banjo.
The skin used depends on the genre of music and the skill of the player.
The three strings of the shamisen are made of either silk  traditionally  or nylon.
The head of the instrument known as a tenjin may also be protected by a cover.
The material of the strings will depend on the skill of the player.
Traditionally  silk strings are used.
However  silk breaks easily over a short time  so this is reserved for professional performances.
The bachi used will also be different according to genre  if it is used at all.
Shamisen are classified according to size and genre.
There are three basic sizes  hosozao  chuzao and futozao.
The hosozao is also often used in kouta  geisha music   where it is plucked with the fingernails.
Chuzao The chuzao  中棹  literally  middle neck   is a size up from the hosozao.
As its name implies  the neck is slightly thicker.
The result is an extended fingerboard that gives the chuzao a higher register than the hosozao.
The chuzao is favored for jiuta style playing  with a broader  more mellow timbre.
It is also an  all round  instrument that can actually be used across many genres.
The bachi used for nagauta shamisen are made out of three possible materials  i.e.
There are sometimes also jiuta bachi that are made with a buffalo horn handle.
The material however makes no difference in the sound.
The bachi used for tsugaru jamisen is the smallest.
It is almost always tipped with tortoiseshell.
The higher the koma  the louder the sound will be  and the harder it is to control a rapid  sukui .
The higher koma are not suitable for beginners.
Ox Bone or shari is the most popular koma for practice and with students who are performing.
Jiuta Koma Heights used  2.6 and 2.8 are the standard.
Other heights may be available if specially ordered.
Koma for jiuta are made out of a few select materials   i.e.
yellow or black water buffalo horn  suigyu  are the standard for jiuta.
Yellow suigyu is the most widely used for jiuta style shamisen  both in practice and performance.
Plastic is available because of the higher price tag of suigyu.
Plastic makes a deader sound  which is not the most favorable for jiuta.
Shari is used from time to time in practice  but never for jiuta performances.
Tsugaru koma are very thin in width  and are not very high.
There is little room for variation.
As a more open instrument  variations of it exist for show.
Variations in playing     In most genres  the shamisen strings are plucked with a bachi.
Sometimes  the shamisen is bowed with a violin bow  similar to the kokyū  a similar instrument.
Tuning    The shamisen is played and tuned according to genre.
The nomenclature of the nodes in an octave also varies according to genre.
E  A  D  G  B  E  or a violin  i.e.
As a consequence  tablature for each genre is written differently.
The nodes are also labeled differently for Tsugaru style shamisen.
What tuning a work calls for is usually indicated on the tablature.
Both men and women traditionally played the shamisen.

Lake Biwa  Japan s largest  is located at the center of this prefecture.

Most other natural rivers flow into the lake.

Economy     Cultivated areas occupy nearly one sixth of the prefecture.
Rice is the principal crop  over 90 percent of the farmlands are rice fields.

Shiga is also famous for high quality wagyū  Ōmi beef.

Shikoku  四国  literally  four provinces   is one of the five main islands of Japan.
Shikoku is the second smallest main island after Okinawa.
It is 225 km or 139.8 mi long and between 50 and 150 km or 31.1 and 93.2 mi wide.
It has a population of 3.8 million  as of 2015  3.1  .
It is south of Honshu and northeast of Kyushu.
The Hydrangea hirta species can be found in these mountain ranges.
Mount Ishizuchi  石鎚山  in Ehime at 1 982 m  6 503 ft  is the highest mountain on the island.
The larger southern area of Shikoku is mountainous and sparsely populated.
The only significant lowland is a small alluvial plain at Kōchi  the prefectural capital.
Two crops of rice can be cultivated annually in the southern area.
The pulp and paper industry took advantage of the abundant forests and hydroelectric power.
The major river in Shikoku is the Yoshino River.
The island s northernmost point is in Takamatsu  Kagawa.
Population    Shikoku has a total population of 3 845 534 in 2015.
The largest city is Matsuyama  population  509 835  and is the capital of Ehime Prefecture.

Middle Ages     During the Muromachi period  Izumo and Oki were controlled by the Kyogoku clan.

Also  Tottori Prefecture was added in the same year.
Geography    Shimane Prefecture is situated on the Sea of Japan side of the Chūgoku region.

Mergers          Climate    The prefecture has a sub tropical climate.
Winter is cloudy with a little snow  and summer is humid.
The average annual temperature is 14.6 °C  58.3 °F .
It rains almost every day in the rainy season  from June to mid July.

Shinto  also known as kami no michi  is a religion which originated in Japan.
There is no central authority in control of Shinto and much diversity exists among practitioners.
The kami are worshiped at kamidana household shrines  family shrines  and jinja public shrines.
This is done to cultivate harmony between humans and kami and to solicit the latter s blessing.
Other common rituals include the kagura dances  rites of passage  and seasonal festivals.
Public shrines also supply religious paraphernalia such as amulets to the religion s adherents.
Buddhism entered Japan at the end of the Kofun period  300 to 538 CE  and spread rapidly.
In ensuing centuries  shinbutsu shūgō was adopted by Japan s Imperial household.
Following Japan s defeat in World War II  Shinto was formally separated from the state.
Numerically  it is Japan s largest religion  the second being Buddhism.
Aspects of Shinto have also been incorporated into various Japanese new religious movements.
Definition      There is no universally agreed definition of Shinto.
Categorization     Many scholars describe Shinto as a religion.
Japanese religion is therefore highly pluralistic.
Scholars of religion have debated how to classify Shinto.
Inoue considered it part of  the family of East Asian religions .
Many scholars regard this classification as inaccurate.
Different types of Shinto have been identified.
It appears in this form in texts such as Nakatomi no harai kunge and Shintōshū tales.
The term Shinto became common in the 15th century.
This use of the term Shinto became increasingly popular from the 18th century.
Dead humans are sometimes venerated as kami  being regarded as protector or ancestral figures.
In Japanese culture  ancestors can be viewed as a form of kami.
In Western Japan  the term jigami is used to describe the enshrined kami of a village founder.
Hachiman for instance has around 25 000 shrines dedicated to him.
The new  subsidiary shrine is known as a bunsha.
In some periods  fees were charged for the right to enshrine a particular kami in a new place.
Shinto cosmology also includes bakemono  spirits who cause malevolent acts.
Bakemono include oni  tengu  kappa  mononoke  and yamanba.

Practice    Shinto tends to focus on ritual behavior rather than doctrine.

The inner sanctuary in which the kami is believed to live is known as a honden.

On a lower level can be found the hall of offerings  known as a heiden.

The chief priest at a shrine is known as a gūji.

19th century     During the 19th century  shotguns were mainly employed by cavalry units.
Both sides of the American Civil War employed shotguns.

Daniel Myron LeFever is credited with the invention of the American hammerless shotgun.
This gun was cocked with external cocking levers on the side of the breech.
He went on to patent the first truly automatic hammerless shotgun in 1883.
This gun automatically cocked itself when the breech was closed.
He later developed the mechanism to automatically eject the shells when the breech was opened.
While working for Winchester Firearms  Browning revolutionized shotgun design.

The Browning Auto 5 remained in production until 1998.

From the reader s point of view  kanji are said to have one or more different  readings .
They cover all readings adopted from the Heian era to the Edo period.
This is also known as Tōsō on  唐宋音  Tang and Song sound .
For instance  the character for east  東  has the on yomi tō  from Middle Chinese tung.
However  Japanese already had two words for  east   higashi and azuma.
Thus the kanji 東 had the latter readings added as kun yomi.
Kun yomi are characterized by the strict  C V syllable structure of yamato kotoba.
It has an alternative spelling as 受け賜る u ke  tamawa ru   hence  1 1  3 5.
志 is a nominalization of the verb 志す which has a long reading kokoroza su .
This is due to its being derived from a noun verb compound  心指す kokoro za su .
The nominalization removes the okurigana  hence increasing the reading by one mora  yielding 4 1 5.
In a number of cases  multiple kanji were assigned to cover a single Japanese word.
Typically when this occurs  the different kanji refer to specific shades of meaning.
For instance  the word なおす  naosu  when written 治す  means  to heal an illness or sickness .
When written 直す it means  to fix or correct something .
Sometimes the distinction is very clear  although not always.
Ateji     Ateji  当て字  宛字 or あてじ  are characters used only for their sounds.
Therefore  only the full compound—not the individual character—has a reading.
It is the other way around with yutō  kun on .
These are the Japanese form of hybrid words.
Ateji often use mixed readings.
Jukujikun are when the standard kanji for a word are related to the meaning  but not the sound.
The word is pronounced as a whole  not corresponding to sounds of individual kanji.
Examples of jukujikun for inflectional words follow.
See 義訓 and 熟字訓 for many more examples.
Many jukujikun  established meaning spellings  began life as gikun  improvised meaning spellings .
The readings are also written in katakana  unlike the usual hiragana for native kun yomi.
Place names sometimes also use nanori or  occasionally  unique readings not found elsewhere.
For example  鉄  iron  is usually read with the on yomi tetsu rather than the kun yomi kurogane.
For example  赤い aka i  red   新しい atara shii  new   見る mi ru   to  see .

Rivers      Most of the rivers arise in the Slovak mountains.

During night it may be freezing  but usually not below −10 °C  14 °F .
The dry continental air brings in the summer heat and winter frosts.
In contrast  oceanic air brings rainfalls and reduces summer temperatures.
In the lowlands and valleys  there is often fog  especially in winter.
In Slovakia  the weather and climate in the spring are very unstable.
The average temperature in September is around 14 °C  57 °F   in November to 3 °C  37 °F .
Late September and early October is a dry and sunny time of year  so called Indian summer .
Winter starts on 21 December with temperatures around −5 to −10 °C  23 to 14 °F .
In December and January  it is usually snowing  these are the coldest months of the year.
At lower altitudes  snow does not stay the whole winter  it changes into the thaw and frost.
The geographical position of Slovakia determines the richness of the diversity of fauna and flora.

Demographics     The population is over 5.4 million and consists mostly of Slovaks.
The average population density is 110 inhabitants per km2.

In the 1990 US census  1.8 million people self identified as having Slovak ancestry.

Climate      Slovenia is located in temperate latitudes.
In the coastal region  there is sub Mediterranean climate.
The average wind speeds are lower than in the plains of the nearby countries.
Due to the rugged terrain  local vertical winds with daily periods are present.
The jugo and the bora are characteristic of the Littoral.
Whereas the jugo is humid and warm  the bora is usually cold and gusty.
The foehn is typical of the Alpine regions in the north of Slovenia.
Generally present in Slovenia are the northeast wind  the southeast wind and the north wind.
Around 12.5  of the territory is protected with 35.5  in the Natura 2000 ecological network.

There are numerous deer  roe deer  boar  and hares.
The edible dormouse is often found in the Slovenian beech forests.

There are hedgehogs  martens  and snakes such as vipers and grass snakes.

They have been preserved ex situ and in situ.
The marble trout or marmorata  Salmo marmoratus  is an indigenous Slovenian fish.
Slovenia is also home to the wels catfish.
Many more remain to be discovered.
The forests are an important natural resource  and logging is kept to a minimum.
In the interior of the country are typical Central European forests  predominantly oak and beech.
In the mountains  spruce  fir  and pine are more common.
The lime linden tree  common in Slovenian forests  is a national symbol.

Temperatures     Several methods have been used to define the subtropical climate.
The frost line separates the warm temperate region from the subtropical region.
It represents the dividing line between two major physiological groups of evolved plants.

The 1814 campaign was the last time Sweden was at war.
Modern history      The Swedish East India Company  Ostindiska Kompaniet  began in 1731.
Between 1750 and 1850  the population in Sweden doubled.
Many looked towards America for a better life during this time.
It is thought that between 1850 and 1910 more than one million Swedes moved to the United States.
In 1889 The Swedish Social Democratic Party was founded.
Sweden also supplied steel and machined parts to Germany throughout the war.
Sweden received aid under the Marshall Plan and participated in the OECD.
In the 1980s several key Swedish industries were significantly restructured.
Eventually the government began to spend over half of the country s gross domestic product.
Swedish GDP per capita ranking declined during this time.
Sweden s GDP declined by around 5 .
Sweden joined the European Union on 1 January 1995.
In a 2003 referendum the Swedish electorate voted against the country joining the Euro currency.
Among others  Swedish companies export weapons that were used by the American military in Iraq.
Sweden also participated in enforcing a UN mandated no fly zone over Libya during the Arab Spring.
Sweden held the chair of the European Union from 1 July to 31 December 2009.
The influx of immigrants has brought new social challenges.
Finland is located to its north east.
Its border with Norway  1 619 km long  is the longest uninterrupted border within Europe.
The highest point is Kebnekaise at 2 111 m  6 926 ft  above sea level.
Sweden has 25 provinces or landskap  based on culture  geography and history.
The sparsely populated Norrland encompasses almost 60  of the country.
About 15  of Sweden lies north of the Arctic Circle.
Southern Sweden is predominantly agricultural  with increasing forest coverage northward.
Around 65  of Sweden s total land area is covered with forests.
Gotland and Öland are Sweden s largest islands  Vänern and Vättern are its largest lakes.
Vänern is the third largest in Europe  after Lake Ladoga and Lake Onega in Russia.
Because of Sweden s high latitude  the length of daylight varies greatly.
Sweden receives between 1 100 and 1 900 hours of sunshine annually.
During July there is not much difference in temperature between the north and south of the country.
The cold winters occur when low pressure systems are weaker.
Nights normally remain cool  especially in inland areas.
Summers can be cool  especially in the north of the country.
Despite northerly locations  southern and central Sweden may have almost no snow in some winters.
Sweden is divided in five major vegetation zones.
The region is characterised by a large wealth of trees and shrubs.
The beech are the most dominant tree  but oak can also form smaller forests.
elm at one time formed forests  but have been heavily reduced due to Dutch Elm disease.
Spruce is not native but between approximately 1870 and 1980  large areas were planted with it.
This is however not the case with oak and ash.
The northern coniferous forest zone  or the Taiga begins north of the natural boundary of the oak.
Of deciduous species the birch is the only one of significance.
The local authorities have self rule  as mandated by the Constitution  and their own tax base.
General elections are held every four years  on the second Sunday of September.
Legislation may be initiated by the Government or by members of the Riksdag.
Members are elected on the basis of proportional representation to a four year term.
There is no stare decisis in that courts are not bound by precedent  although it is influential.
After 1932  most governments have been dominated by the Social Democrats.
The 1994 election saw the return of the Greens and the demise of New Democracy.
The Alliance won a plurality of 173 seats  but remained two seats short of a 175 seat majority.
The non aligned Sweden Democrats more than doubled their support and won the remaining 49 seats.
Every county council corresponds to a county  län  with a number of municipalities per county.
Municipalities are also divided into a total of 2 512 parishes  församlingar .
Political history      The actual age of the kingdom of Sweden is unknown.

Sweden has low levels of burglary  car theft and drug problems.

During World War II Sweden joined neither the allied nor axis powers.
The function of the Swedish military was to deter attack.
In 1952  a Swedish DC 3 was shot down over the Baltic Sea by a Soviet MiG 15 jet fighter.
Later investigations revealed that the plane was actually gathering information for NATO.
The incident triggered a diplomatic crisis between Sweden and the Soviet Union.
Military      The law is enforced in Sweden by several government entities.
The Swedish police is a Government agency concerned with police matters.
The National Task Force is a national SWAT unit within the police force.
The armed forces are divided into Army  Air Force and Navy.
By law  all soldiers serving abroad must be volunteers.
In 1975  the total number of conscripts was 45 000.
By 2003  it was down to 15 000.
The total forces gathered would consist of about 60 000 personnel.

As the law is now gender neutral  both men and women may have to serve.

Public policy      Sweden has one of the most highly developed welfare states in the world.
After World War II a succession of governments expanded the welfare state by raising the taxes.
During this period Sweden s economic growth was also one of the highest in the industrial world.
Growth has been higher than in many other EU 15 countries.
Sweden is starting to look like the USA.
Nevertheless  it remains far more egalitarian than most nations.

Science and technology      In the 18th century  Sweden s scientific revolution took off.
Previously  technical progress had mainly come from mainland Europe.
Many of the companies founded by early pioneers still remain major international brands.
Gustaf Dalén founded AGA  and received the Nobel Prize for his sun valve.
Alfred Nobel invented dynamite and instituted the Nobel Prizes.
Tetra Pak was an invention for storing liquid foods  invented by Erik Wallenberg.
For several decades the Swedish government has prioritised scientific and R D activities.
Sweden tops other European countries in the number of published scientific works per capita.

Modern history      Switzerland was not invaded during either of the world wars.

Ecology     The typical structure of these forests includes four layers.
Below the sub canopy is the shrub layer  composed of low growing woody plants.
Typically the lowest growing  and most diverse  layer is the ground cover or herbaceous layer.
Typical coniferous trees include pines  Pinus spp.
Temperate coniferous forest is a terrestrial biome defined by the World Wide Fund for Nature.
A separate habitat type  the tropical coniferous forests  occurs in more tropical climates.
Many species of trees inhabit these forests including pine  cedar  fir  and redwood.
The understory also contains a wide variety of herbaceous and shrub species.
However  some forests may support a layer of shrubs.

Politics and government     Prior to 1932  Thai kings were absolute monarchs.
The system of government was a network of tributaries ruled by local lords.
Thailand has had the fourth most coups in the world.
Uniformed or ex military men have led Thailand for 55 of the 83 years  between 1932 and 2009.
Most recently  the National Council for Peace and Order ruled the country between 2014 and 2019.
The current King of Thailand is Vajiralongkorn  or Rama X   who has reigned since October 2016.
The powers of the king are limited by the constitution and he is primarily a symbolic figurehead.
He has the power to appoint his heirs  the power to grant pardons  and the royal assent.
The king is aided in his duties by the Privy Council of Thailand.
The monarchy is widely revered and lèse majesté is a severe crime in Thailand.
Its most recent election is the 2019 general election.
The coalition led by Palang Pracharath Party currently holds the majority.
The cabinet was appointed by the king on the advice of the prime minister.
The prime minister is the head of government.
Most parties in Thailand are short lived.
Between 1992 and 2006  Thailand had a two party system.
Thailand has been rated not free on the Freedom House Index since 2014.
The northeast  Isan  consists of the Khorat Plateau  bordered to the east by the Mekong River.

The diversity of the regions is the most pronounced attribute of Thailand s physical setting.
The Chao Phraya and the Mekong River are the indispensable water courses of rural Thailand.
Industrial scale production of crops use both rivers and their tributaries.
The Andaman Sea is a precious natural resource as it hosts popular and luxurious resorts.
Most of the country is classified as Köppen s tropical savanna climate.

The country receives a mean annual rainfall of 1 200 to 1 600 mm  47 to 63 in .
Winter or the northeast monsoon occurs from mid–October until mid–February.
Most of Thailand experiences dry weather with mild temperatures.
Summer or the pre–monsoon season runs from mid–February until mid–May.

Economy     Thailand is an emerging economy and is considered a newly industrialised country.
Thailand had a 2017 GDP of US 1.236 trillion  on a purchasing power parity basis .
Thailand is the 2nd largest economy in Southeast Asia after Indonesia.
The baht was pegged at 25 to the US dollar from 1978 to 1997.
Growth in 2002  2003  and 2004 was 5–7  annually.
Growth in 2005  2006  and 2007 hovered around 4–5 .
Top quintile households had a 45.0  share of all income  while bottom quintile households had 7.1 .
The top 10  richest held 79  of the country s assets.
The top 1  richest held 58  of the assets.
At the end of 2017  Thailand s total household debt was ฿11.76 trillion.
In 2010  3  of all household were bankrupt.
In 2016  there were estimated 30 000 homeless persons in the country.
Eight manufacturers  five Japanese  two US  and Tata of India  produce pick up trucks in Thailand.
As of 2012  Thailand was the second largest consumer of pick up trucks in the world  after the US.
In 2014  pick ups accounted for 42  of all new vehicle sales in Thailand.

Drama     Tibetan folk opera  known as lhamo  is a combination of dances  chants and songs.
The repertoire is drawn from Buddhist stories and Tibetan history.
The performance is usually a drama  held on a barren stage that combines dances  chants  and songs.
The performance starts with a stage purification and blessings.
A narrator then sings a summary of the story  and the performance begins.
Another ritual blessing is conducted at the end of the play.

He was then allowed to return to Mikawa Province.
The lord of Terabe  Suzuki Shigeteru  betrayed the Imagawa by defecting to Oda Nobunaga.
Imagawa Yoshimoto  leading a large army of 25 000 men  invaded Oda clan territory.
Motoyasu was assigned a separate mission to capture the stronghold of Marune.
Motoyasu then decided to ally with Oda Nobunaga.
Kaminogō was held by Udono Nagamochi.
In the same year in February  Motoyasu changed his name to Ieyasu.
For the next few years Ieyasu was occupied with reforming the Matsudaira clan and pacifying Mikawa.
He also strengthened his key vassals by awarding them land and castles.
Tokugawa clan      In 1565  Matsudaira Ieyasu became master of all of Mikawa Province.
However  there was no proof the Matsudaira clan are descendants of Emperor Seiwa.
At the same time  Ieyasu was eager to expand eastward to Tōtōmi province.
Meanwhile  Shingen s troops captured Suruga Province  including the Imagawa capital of Sunpu .
Imagawa Ujizane fled to Kakegawa Castle  which lead to Ieyasu to lead the Siege of Kakegawa.
Soon Nobunaga was ready to punish Nagamasa for his treachery.
Ieyasu led 5 000 of his men to support Nobunaga at the battle.
The Battle of Anegawa occurred near Lake Biwa in Ōmi Province  Japan.
It is notable as the first battle that involved the alliance between Nobunaga and Ieyasu.
Later  Ieyasu asked for help from Nobunaga  who sent him some 3 000 troops.
Early in 1573 the two armies met at the Battle of Mikatagahara  north Hamamatsu.
Despite his initial reticence  Ieyasu was convinced by his generals to retreat.
In 1574  Katsuyori took Takatenjin fortress.
Ieyasu appealed to Nobunaga for help and Nobunaga came with 30 000 strong men.
The Oda Tokugawa forces of 38 000 won a great victory and successfully defended Nagashino castle.
Though Takeda forces destroyed  Katsuyori survived the battle and retreated back to Kai Province.
For this reason  Ieyasu ordered his wife to be executed and forced his son to commit seppuku.
Takeda Katsuyori was defeated at the Battle of Tenmokuzan  and then committed seppuku.
Later  Ieyasu traveled back to Mikawa for gathering his forces.
He returned to his home Mikawa Province by sea.
Because of this  Ieyasu promptly invaded Kai and took control.
Hideyoshi defeated Katsuie at Battle of Shizugatake.
With this victory  Hideyoshi became the single most powerful daimyō in Japan.
Hideyoshi responded by sending an army into Owari.
First  Hideyoshi made peace with Oda Nobukatsu  and then he offered a truce to Ieyasu.
However  few other Tokugawa retainers followed this example.
The Hōjō clan ruled the eight provinces of the Kantō region in eastern Japan.
Hideyoshi ordered them to submit to his authority and they refused.
Odawara Campaign is the first battle of Ieyasu and Hideyoshi as allies.
He himself occupied the castle town of Edo in Kantō.
In the end  it worked out brilliantly for Ieyasu.
Within a few years  Ieyasu had become the second most powerful daimyō in Japan.
He stayed in Nagoya off and on for the next five years.
In 1593  Toyotomi Hideyoshi fathered a son and heir  Toyotomi Hideyori.
Mitsunari plotted Ieyasu s death and news of this plot reached some of Ieyasu s generals.
Ieyasu supported the anti Mitsunari Group  and formed them as his potential allies.
Ieyasu held a meeting with the daimyō  and they agreed to follow Ieyasu.
On August 23  Ieyasu s army took Gifu castle.
On October 20  they meet at Sekigahara  Gifu and the battle began.
Ieyasu had also sneaked in a supply of arquebuses.
Tozama daimyō were considered inferior to fudai daimyō.
He had outlasted all the other great men of his times  Nobunaga  Shingen  Hideyoshi  and Kenshin.
He claimed descent from the Minamoto clan  by way of the Nitta clan.
His descendants would marry into the Taira clan and the Fujiwara clan.
His successor was his son and heir  Tokugawa Hidetada.
The edict banned the practice of Christianity and led to the expulsion of all foreign missionaries.
He was now a young daimyō living in Osaka Castle.
Then in 1614  Tokugawa besieged the Osaka Castle against Hideyori.
His wife  Senhime  a granddaughter of Ieyasu   pleaded to save Hideyori and Yodo dono s lives.
Ieyasu refused and either required them to commit ritual suicide  or killed both of them.
Eventually  Senhime was sent back to Tokugawa alive.
After killing two people at Kamakura  who have escaped from Osaka Castle.
Death     In 1616  Ieyasu died at age 73.
The cause of death is thought to have been cancer or syphilis.
His remains were buried at the Gongens  mausoleum at Kunōzan  Kunōzan Tōshō gū  久能山東照宮 .
The mausoleum s architectural style became known as gongen zukuri  that is gongen style.
Ieyasu s character     Ieyasu had a number of qualities that enabled him to rise to power.
He was both careful and bold—at the right times  and in the right places.
Calculating and subtle  Ieyasu switched alliances when he thought he would benefit from the change.
In this he was like other daimyō of his time.
This was an era of violence  sudden death  and betrayal.
He was known for being loyal towards his personal friends and vassals  whom he rewarded.
He was said to have a close friendship with his vassal Hattori Hanzō.
However  he also remembered those who had wronged him in the past.
At the same time  he could be ruthless when crossed.
He regarded it as excellent training for a warrior.
You exercise your muscles and train your limbs.
Let thy step be slow and steady  that thou stumble not.
When ambitious desires arise in thy heart  recall the days of extremity thou hast passed through.
Forbearance is the root of all quietness and assurance forever.
The strong manly ones in life are those who understand the meaning of the word patience.
Patience means restraining one s inclinations.
I am not as strong as I might be  but I have long known and practiced patience.
And if my descendants wish to be as I am  they must study patience.
Toranaga was portrayed by Toshiro Mifune in the 1980 TV mini series adaptation.

It was adapted into an anime series in 2011  and includes a fictional depiction of Tokugawa s life.

However  Tadakatsu advised for his lord to avoid the risk and urged for a quick retreat to Mikawa.
Masanari led the way through Iga and they returned home by boat.
Together  they planned when to attack and went their separate ways.
After the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600  central authority fell to Tokugawa Ieyasu.
Baku is an abbreviation of bakufu  meaning  military government —that is  the shogunate.
The han were the domains headed by daimyō.
One koku was the amount of rice necessary to feed one adult male for one year.
They would provide an heir to the shogunate if the shogun didn t have an heir.
They were often placed in mountainous or far away areas  or placed between most trusted daimyos.
These four states are called the Four Western Clans  or Satchotohi for short.
Foreign trade was also permitted to the Satsuma and the Tsushima domains.
Rice was the main trading product of Japan during this time.
Isolationism was the foreign policy of Japan and trade was strictly controlled.
Merchants were outsiders to the social hierarchy of Japan and were thought to be greedy.
From 1603 onward  Japan started to participate actively in foreign trade.
His successors followed suit  compounding upon Ieyasu s laws.
Special levies were also imposed for infrastructure building.
The roju conferred on especially important matters.
However  there were exceptions to both criteria.
Irregularly  the shōguns appointed a rōjū to the position of tairō  great elder .
Three to five men titled the wakadoshiyori  若年寄  were next in status below the rōjū.
Under the wakadoshiyori were the metsuke.
Some shōguns appointed a soba yōnin.
This person acted as a liaison between the shōgun and the rōjū.
Fearing for his personal safety  Tsunayoshi moved the rōjū to a more distant part of the castle.
Some of the most famous soba yōnin were Yanagisawa Yoshiyasu and Tanuma Okitsugu.
The five ōmetsuke were in charge of monitoring the affairs of the daimyōs  kuge and imperial court.
They were in charge of discovering any threat of rebellion.
Early in the Edo period  daimyōs such as Yagyū Munefuyu held the office.
Soon  however  it fell to hatamoto with rankings of 5 000 koku or more.
The metsuke  reporting to the wakadoshiyori  oversaw the affairs of the vassals of the shōgun.
They were the police force for the thousands of hatamoto and gokenin who were concentrated in Edo.
Individual han had their own metsuke who similarly policed their samurai.
The jisha bugyō had the highest status of the three.
Also  they heard lawsuits from several land holdings outside the eight Kantō provinces.
The four holders of this office reported to the rōjū.
The shogun directly held lands in various parts of Japan.
Gaikoku bugyō     The gaikoku bugyō were administrators appointed between 1858 and 1868.
It is at the end of the Edo period and preceded the Meiji era.
History     Until the Meiji Restoration  Tokushima Prefecture was known as Awa Province.
At the time  it included the Awa region to the south and the Awaji Island regions as well.
In 1873 it further incorporated the region currently occupied by Kagawa Prefecture in its borders.

The Izu Islands are a group of volcanic islands and form part of the Fuji Hakone Izu National Park.

Etymology    The word  Tottori  in Japanese is formed from two kanji characters.
The first  鳥  means  bird  and the second  取 means  to get .
Early residents in the area made their living catching the region s plentiful waterfowl.
The imperial Prince Homatsu wake was unable to speak  despite being 30 years of age.
Yukuha Tana presented the swan to the emperor.
Homatsu wake no Mikoto played with this swan and at last learned to speak.
Therefore  Yukaha Tana was liberally rewarded  and was granted the title of Tottori no Miyakko.

Ukiyo e is a genre of Japanese art which flourished from the 17th through 19th centuries.
The term ukiyo e  浮世絵  translates as  picture s  of the floating world .
In 1603  the city of Edo  Tokyo  became the seat of the ruling Tokugawa shogunate.
Colour prints were introduced gradually  and at first were only used for special commissions.
By the 1740s  artists such as Okumura Masanobu used multiple woodblocks to print areas of colour.
Some ukiyo e artists specialized in making paintings  but most works were prints.
Until the 17th century  such printing was reserved for Buddhist seals and images.
The paintings of Iwasa Matabei  1578–1650  have a great affinity with ukiyo e paintings.
Chōshun allowed greater expressive freedom in his adherents  a group that later included Hokusai.
His restrained  graceful prints invoked the classicism of waka poetry and Yamato e painting.
The prolific Harunobu was the dominant ukiyo e artist of his time.
Colours tend to be softer and pigments thicker in Kamigata prints than in those of Edo.
In the 19th century many of the prints were designed by kabuki fans and other amateurs.
One of those rivals was Eisen  1790–1848   who was also adept at landscapes.
Ukiyo e prints were amongst the items he brought back to the United States.
Van Gogh was an avid collector  and painted copies in oil of prints by Hiroshige and Eisen.
He signed much of this work with his initials in a circle  imitating the seals on Japanese prints.
The movement favoured individuality in its artists  and as such has no dominant themes or styles.
Elements of images were often cropped  giving the composition a spontaneous feel.
In colour prints  contours of most colour areas are sharply defined  usually by the linework.
E hon books of illustrations were popular and continued be an important outlet for ukiyo e artists.
Nearly every ukiyo e master produced shunga at some point.
Trade  primarily with the Dutch and Chinese  was restricted to the island of Dejima near Nagasaki.
Outlandish pictures called Nagasaki e were sold to tourists of the foreigners and their wares.
Publishing was highly competitive  over a thousand publishers are known from throughout the period.
The woodblocks were also traded or sold to other publishers or pawnshops.
Publishers were usually also vendors  and commonly sold each other s wares in their shops.
Young designers could be expected to cover part or all of the costs of cutting the woodblocks.
An artist s name consisted of a gasei artist surname followed by an azana personal art name.
Retailers and travelling sellers promoted them at prices affordable to prosperous townspeople.
In some cases the prints advertised kimono designs by the print artist.
The mid 1760s brought full colour nishiki e prints made from ten or more woodblocks.
Printers first used natural colour dyes made from mineral or vegetable sources.
The colours were harsher and brighter than traditional pigments.
The Meiji government promoted their use as part of broader policies of Westernization.

The wildlife of Japan includes its flora  fauna and natural habitats.
This results in a high diversity of wildlife despite Japan s isolation from the mainland of Asia.
In the south there are south east Asian species  typical of tropical regions.
Between these areas lies the temperate zone which shares many species with China and Korea.
The largest of these are the two bears.
The Asian black bear  Ursus thibetanus  inhabits mountainous areas in Honshū  Kyūshū and Shikoku.
Large numbers of migrant birds pass through Japan in spring and autumn including many waders.
In winter  several sites are important for swans  geese and cranes.
Fish      Over 3000 different types of fish have been recorded in Japan.
The common carp is the ancestor of the well known domestic koi carp.
Also present is the Japanese dace  Tribolodon hakonensis .
Important saltwater fish include the red sea bream  Pagrus major .
The winter spawning Japanese Flying Squid are associated with the Kuroshio Current.
There are around 190 dragonflies including the primitive Epiophlebia superstes.
Other well known insects in Japan include cicadas  crickets and fireflies.
Firefly viewing is a popular tourist attraction in some areas.
One example is Niphanda fusca  a parasitic butterfly that commonly resides in satoyama.
It is one of the four species that have disappeared in Shikoku.
Molluscs          Flora     Around 4000 to 6000 species of plants occur naturally in Japan.
In the subtropical zone  mangroves  cycads and tree ferns can be found.
Conifer plantations have replaced natural forest in many areas.
The last is Japan s tallest conifer reaching 40 metres in height.
Native food plants include the water dropwort  Oenanthe javanica  and wasabi.

From the late Edo period  the status of women declined.
Modesty extended to the effective use of silence in both daily conversations and activities.
Tidiness included personal appearance and a clean home.
Self reliance of women was encouraged because needy women were seen as a burden on others.
This allowed them greater freedom  equality to men  and a higher status within Japanese society.
In 1986  the Equal Employment Opportunity Law took effect.
Legally  few barriers to women s equal participation in the life of society remain.
In a global survey of women in parliaments  Japan ranked 123rd out of 189 countries.
In the lower house of the Diet  women hold only 8  of seats  with 19  in the upper house.
Women are often found in part time or temporary jobs.
77  of these jobs were filled by women in 2012.
Among women who do work  women only unions are small in size and in relative power.
Japan has a strong tradition of women being housewives after marriage.
However  children were assumed to remain with the male head of the household.
Raising children and keeping household affairs in order were seen as women s role in the state.

The Japanese water based inks provide a wide range of vivid colors  glazes  and transparency.
However  western printing press were discontinued after the ban on Christianity in 1614.
By 1640 woodblocks were once again used for nearly all purposes.
One of the most famous and successful was Tsuta ya.
Technique     The technique for printing texts and images was generally similar.
Oil could be used to make the lines of the image more visible.
An incision is made along both sides of each line or area.
Wood is then chiseled away  based on the drawing outlines.
The sheet of paper to be printed is placed in the  kento  then lowered onto the woodblock.
Printers often used gold  mica  and other substances to enhance the image further.

Constitutional role    The Yang di Pertuan Agong s role is that of a constitutional monarch.
The Constitution vests the executive power of the federal government in the monarch.
Thus  in practice  most of the actual day to day work of governing is performed by the Cabinet.
Conventionally  the Prime Minister is the head of the party with a majority in Parliament.
It  however  does not afford him the right and authority to dismiss the prime minister.
The constitution established procedures for such appointments.
The Yang di Pertuan Agong also appoints the Mayor and City Council of Kuala Lumpur.
In this role  he is advised by the State Islamic Affairs Council in each of the States.
The Yang di Pertuan Agong appoints the chairman and members of each council.
He also appoints the State Mufti in each of these states.
There is a single Islamic Affairs Council with jurisdiction for the three Federal Territories.
This council is also appointed by the Yang di Pertuan Agong.
As such  he is the highest ranking officer in the military chain of command.
He also appoints the service heads of each of the three branches of the military forces.
The new Yang di Pertuan Agong is elected for a full five year term.
Since then  the states have followed a de facto established rotation order.
Minors are automatically disqualified from office.
The Conference of Rulers has met regularly since 1985.
Qualifications     Only a ruler may be elected.
The ruler has notified the Keeper of the Rulers’ Seal that he does not wish to be elected.
The resolution requires at least five members of the Conference to vote in favour of it.
Election proceedings      The election is carried out by a secret ballot.
Only the Rulers participate in the election.
Rulers are named and stand for election in turn.
Usually  but not always  the regent is a close relative.
This cycle was originally established based on seniority.
As an elective monarchy  there is no line of succession to the throne of Malaysia.
Four of the states of Malaysia currently have no hereditary royal rulers.
The right to sue a ruler is limited to Malaysian citizens following a precedent.
The Special Court also have jurisdiction where a ruler initiates legal actions against any party.
In such case  they may request clemency from the Conference of Rulers.
Any claims can be made against the federal government.
It is also the venue of meetings of the Conference of Rulers.

Features     The Yayoi period is generally accepted to date from 300 BC to 300 AD.
Yayoi culture quickly spread to the main island of Honshū  mixing with native Jōmon culture.
Yayoi craft specialists made bronze ceremonial bells  dōtaku   mirrors  and weapons.
By the 1st century AD  Yayoi people began using iron agricultural tools and weapons.

Although the battles in Kyoto had been abandoned  the war had spread to the rest of Japan.
This stalemate was to have serious consequences.
Setting up their own army  the Ikki   they forced the clan armies to leave the province.
The Ikki became a powerful force  much more than simply an armed mob.
By 1488 the Ikkō ikki of Kaga Province overthrew Masachika and took control of the province.
Thence began a series of strange conflicts over control of the puppet government of the shogunate.
Kyoto     Kyoto was devastated by the war  not really recovering until the mid 16th century.

To say that the war began with a quarrel between angry warlords is too simplistic.
1445 Hosokawa Katsumoto becomes Kyoto kanrei.
1449 Ashikaga Shigeuji assumes office in the Kantō.
1457 Ōta Dōkan builds Edo Castle.
Ashikaga Masatomo sent to govern the Kantō.
1458 Yoshimasa builds a new Muromachi palace.
1464 Yoshimasa decided to abdicate his position as Shogun to his brother Ashikaga Yoshimi.
1465 Hino Tomiko gives birth to Ashikaga Yoshihisa and calls herself regent to her son.
In November  the Shōkoku ji  相国寺  is destroyed.
1468 Yoshimi goes over to Yamana s side.
Asakura Toshikage becomes Constable  shugo  of Echizen.
1492 Hōjō Sōun becomes master of Izu.
1494 Hosokawa Masamoto becomes Kyoto kanrei.
1545 Hōjō Ujiyasu defeats the Uesugi clan forces at Kawagoe.
1551 Mōri defeats the Ōuchi led by Sue Harukata at the Battle of Miyajima.
1554 Mōri succeeds to Ōuchi lands and power.
